roles.title: FedRAMP Program Management Office
roles.description: The FedRAMP PMO resides within GSA and supports agencies and cloud service providers through the FedRAMP authorization process and maintains a secure repository of FedRAMP authorizations to enable reuse of security packages

roles.title: FedRAMP Program Management Office
roles.description: Members of the JAB include the chief information officers (CIOs) from the Department of Defense, Department of Homeland Security, and General Services Administration. The JAB serves as the primary governance and decision-making body for FedRAMP.

roles.title: Prepared By
roles.description: The organization that prepared this SSP. If developed in-house, this is the CSP itself.

roles.title: Prepared For
roles.description: The organization for which this SSP was prepared. Typically the CSP.

roles.title: System Security Plan Approval
roles.description: he individual or individuals accountable for the accuracy of this SSP.

roles.title: Cloud Service Provider (CSP) Name
roles.description: Cloud Service Provider used by the client

roles.title: Information System Owner
roles.description: The individual within the CSP who is ultimately accountable for everything related to this system.

roles.title: Authorizing Official
roles.description: The individual or individuals who must grant this system an authorization to operate.

roles.title: Authorizing Official's Point of Contact
roles.description: The individual representing the authorizing official.

roles.title: Information System Management Point of Contact (POC)
roles.description: The highest level manager who responsible for system operation on behalf of the System Owner.

roles.title: Information System Technical Point of Contact
roles.description: The individual or individuals leading the technical operation of the system.

roles.title: System Information System Security Officer (or Equivalent)
roles.description: The individual accountable for the security posture of the system on behalf of the system owner.

roles.title: Privacy Official's Point of Contact
roles.description: The individual responsible for the privacy threshold analysis and if necessary the privacy impact assessment.

roles.title: General Point of Contact (POC)
roles.description: A general point of contact for the system, designated by the system owner.

It is available to [Insert scope of customers in accordance with instructions above (for example, the public, federal, state, local, and tribal governments, as well as research institutions, federal contractors, government contractors etc.)].NOTE: Additional description, including the purpose and functions of this system may be added here. leveraged-authorizations.title: Azure Commercial Cloud
leveraged-authorizations.remarks: Microsoft Azure Commercial Cloud is an open and flexible cloud platform that enables customers to quickly build, test, deploy, and manage their applications, services, and product development across a network of Microsoft-managed datacenters within the United States. The Microsoft Azure platform exports savings to the customer by delivering the software, platform, and IT infrastructure resources where and when it is needed via the Internet. Microsoft Azure provides a multi-tenant public cloud services platform that offers functionality to support capacities such as Platform as a Service (PaaS), and Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) cloud service models. Azure maintains a P-ATO at the High Impact Level. Azure was the first public cloud with IaaS and PaaS services to receive a JAB P-ATO.For additional information, visit the (Azure Trust Center)[https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/TrustCenter/Compliance/default.aspx] or refer to Azure FedRAMP Package ID# F0000000000.The following Microsoft services are FedRAMP Authorized and approved by leveraged-authorizations.title: Zscaler, Inc.
leveraged-authorizations.remarks: Zscaler Internet Access delivers your security stack as a service from the cloud, eliminating the cost and complexity of traditional secure web gateway approaches. By moving security to a globally distributed cloud, Zscaler brings the Internet gateway closer to the user for a faster experience. Organizations can easily scale protection to all offices or users, regardless of location, and minimize network and appliance infrastructure.**The Cloud and Mobility Have Broken Perimeter Security**The data center used to be the center of gravity. When applications resided there, it made sense to backhaul traffic from branch offices over a hub-and-spoke network. As traffic patterns shifted to the Internet, gateways were built with stacks of security appliances to allow secure Internet access. These gateways were also centralized to minimize the cost and complexity of securing multiple locations.However, as applications have moved to the cloud, the center of gravity has moved with it. User traffic often goes straight to the cloud, bypassing the security perimeter. Additionally, today’s complex threats have triggered an explosion of new security appliances, all finding their way into your overworked gateway. Administrators are in a constant battle to keep up with required security updates for their appliances. The complexity of deploying and managing all these appliances — and their associated costs — are out of control. Furthermore, it’s all associated with what is now an outdated architecture.**Zscaler Internet Access**Zscaler Internet Access is a secure Internet and web gateway delivered as a service from the cloud. Think of it as a secure Internet onramp — all you do is make Zscaler your next hop to the Internet. For offices, simply set up a router tunnel (GRE or IPsec) to the closest Zscaler data center. For mobile employees, you can forward traffic via our lightweight Zscaler App or PAC file. No matter where users connect — a coffee shop in Milan, a hotel in Hong Kong, or the office — they get identical protection.Zscaler Internet Access sits between your users and the Internet, inspecting every byte of traffic inline across multiple security techniques, even within SSL. You get full protection from web and Internet threats. And with a cloud platform that supports Cloud Sandboxing, Next-Generation Firewall, Data Loss Prevention (DLP), and Cloud Application Visibility and Control, you can start with the services you need today and activate others as your needs grow.All these capabilities are delivered from the Zscaler Cloud Security Platform, the world’s largest security cloud, which processes more than 30 billion requests a day. With over 100 patents, the Zscaler platform has been architected from the ground up as a truly distributed, multi-tenant cloud with enterprise performance and scale.

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks: In Microsoft Azure Commercial Cloud, authentication is primarily managed through Azure Active Directory (AAD), which provides several methods to ensure secure access to services.1. **Password-Based Authentication**: Users authenticate by entering a username and password. Azure enforces strong password policies to enhance security.2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: Azure supports MFA, requiring users to provide a second form of verification in addition to their password. This can include a text message, phone call, or authentication app notification, adding an extra layer of security.3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: Azure enables SSO, allowing users to access multiple applications with one set of credentials. This is facilitated through AAD, which integrates with various third-party applications and services.4. **Conditional Access Policies**: Azure allows administrators to set conditional access policies that determine how and when users can authenticate based on factors like user location, device compliance, and risk level.These authentication methods are integrated within the Azure platform, ensuring that users can securely access their applications and services while maintaining compliance with security standards.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a structured approach is taken, leveraging security components and DevOps management activities. The process begins by defining non-privileged accounts within Azure Active Directory (AD), ensuring that these accounts are granted only the necessary permissions to perform their designated tasks without access to security functions.Next, role-based access control (RBAC) policies are established within Azure, clearly delineating roles with the principle of least privilege in mind. These roles are then assigned to users based on their job functions, ensuring that no user has more access than required for their role.Azure DevOps Pipelines are configured to enforce these RBAC roles and permissions during deployment and operational activities. This ensures that any changes to the system, including software updates or configuration changes, are executed under non-privileged accounts, reducing the risk of unauthorized access or actions.Regular audits and reviews of user access permissions are conducted to verify compliance with the established RBAC policies. During these reviews, user roles and permissions are checked against the defined non-privileged accounts to ensure they align with the intended access levels for non-security functions.If discrepancies or excess permissions are identified during audits, immediate remediation actions are taken. User roles and permissions are adjusted to conform to the defined policies, and additional training or process adjustments are implemented as needed to prevent recurrence.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a structured approach is implemented to manage privileged accounts. This approach involves a series of security components and DevOps management activities that ensure only specific personnel or roles have elevated access rights.Initially, role-based access control (RBAC) within Azure is configured to define distinct roles with varying levels of privileges. These roles are aligned with the responsibilities and requirements of different personnel within the organization. The creation of these roles is governed by a defined process implemented by ACME that includes approval from senior management to ensure alignment with the principle of least privilege.Once roles are established, user accounts are assigned to these roles based on job function and necessity. This assignment is strictly controlled through a user access management process that requires verification of the individual’s identity and authorization before granting any privileged access.For ongoing management, an automated system monitors and logs all privileged account activity. This ensures that any deviation from expected behavior can be quickly identified and investigated. Regular audits are conducted to review privileged account assignments and activities, ensuring that they remain appropriate and that no unauthorized changes have occurred.Furthermore, any changes to system configurations, especially those affecting key parameters related to security, are restricted to authorized privileged accounts. Change management procedures are in place to document, approve, and monitor any such changes, mitigating the risk of unauthorized modifications that could compromise the system.In cases where local and domain accounts are used, policies are tailored to maintain strict control over both types while still allowing for necessary administrative functions. This may include separate sets of credentials for local and domain accounts, with clear guidelines on when each type of account should be used.All personnel with privileged access are required to undergo specialized training regarding their responsibilities and the proper use of their privileges. They are also made aware of the potential risks associated with misuse or abuse of their elevated rights.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components through the logging and analysis of privileged function use, the following step-by-step process is implemented:1. Privileged function executions are consistently logged across all relevant systems. This is achieved by integrating a defined process implemented by ACME with the cloud infrastructure. The process collects and stores logs of all operations, including those performed with elevated privileges.2. A defined process implemented by ACME is configured to aggregate and analyze the logs collected. This ensures that any misuse of privileged functions can be detected promptly. The process's advanced analytics capabilities allow for the identification of anomalous activities that may indicate a security incident.3. The log entries include comprehensive details such as the identity of the user who executed the privileged function, the exact timestamp of the activity, and a clear description of the action performed. These details are crucial for forensic analysis and accountability.4. A defined process implemented by ACME is utilized to manage secrets and credentials securely, ensuring that access to privileged functions requires proper authentication and authorization. It also logs access to these secrets, adding another layer of auditing.5. A defined process implemented by ACME is employed to manage user identities and permissions. The process provides additional logging capabilities that record when users perform privileged operations, which are then fed into a defined process implemented by ACME for further analysis.6. Log management policies are established to define what data should be logged, how long logs should be retained, and who has access to them. These policies help maintain a balance between security and privacy considerations.7. Regular monitoring routines are set up where security personnel review audit logs within a defined process implemented by ACME to look for indicators of misuse or unauthorized access to privileged functions.8. Automated tools are configured to query log data periodically, ensuring continuous compliance with logging requirements. These tools can generate alerts if they detect anomalies or deviations from expected patterns of privileged function use.9. Security incident response procedures are in place so that if misuse or an anomaly is detected, appropriate actions can be taken swiftly to contain and remediate any potential security breach.10. Continuous improvement practices are adopted where feedback from log analysis and incident response activities inform updates to policies, procedures, and technical controls to enhance detection and prevention of misuse.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a robust access control policy is implemented, leveraging Azure's native security features. This policy ensures that only users with appropriate authorizations can perform privileged functions.Firstly, role-based access control (RBAC) is configured within Azure Active Directory to define roles and assign them to users based on their responsibilities. RBAC roles are granular, ensuring that permissions align closely with the user's job functions. For instance, non-privileged users are restricted from creating system accounts or managing cryptographic keys.In Azure Sentinel, policies are established to prevent non-privileged users from disabling or altering security controls. These policies are enforced by continuous monitoring through Azure Monitor and Azure Log Analytics, which detect any unauthorized attempt to modify security settings.When it comes to system account management in Azure AD, a defined process implemented by ACME is in place to monitor account creation activities. These processes use predefined rules to block attempts made by non-privileged users to establish new system accounts.For cryptographic key management activities within Azure Key Vault, access policies limit operations such as key creation, deletion, and rotation to authorized personnel only. Automated mechanisms verify the identity and permissions of a user before granting access to key management functions.All these measures are continuously reviewed and updated to adapt to evolving threats and ensure compliance with the principle of least privilege. Regular audits and automated alerts help maintain the integrity of the access control system, promptly identifying and responding to any unauthorized actions. These steps collectively safeguard the cloud system against unauthorized access and manipulation of sensitive components and activities.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a device lock mechanism is implemented as part of the security posture. This mechanism involves the use of pattern-hiding displays that activate when devices are idle or upon user action. The device lock is configured to obscure any sensitive information displayed with either static or dynamic images which do not reveal controlled unclassified information.The initial step involves setting up policies within the Device Management framework that mandate the activation of a device lock on all applicable devices after a predefined period of inactivity. These policies specify the use of approved screen savers, photographic images, solid colors, or other non-disclosing visuals.Following policy implementation, all devices are configured to comply with these requirements. Device settings are adjusted to ensure that after the set period of inactivity, the device lock activates, displaying only the approved images or patterns. Additionally, users are trained and required to manually activate the device lock when leaving their devices unattended.Security capabilities are regularly assessed to ensure that they effectively conceal information on displays in public areas. This assessment is conducted manually by checking if the device lock activates as per policy specifications.In case of deviations from the expected behavior during assessments, remediation activities are initiated through a defined process implemented by ACME. This includes reconfiguring device settings, retraining users, or updating policies to address any identified gaps.

by-components.description: The system is designed to mitigate threats associated with inactive user sessions by implementing an automatic session termination feature. This feature is integrated into the user authentication and session management systems, ensuring that once a predefined period of inactivity, as defined by ACME's policy, is reached, the user session is terminated.Upon user login, the session management system initiates a timer which tracks user inactivity. The duration of this timer is set according to the ACME-defined parameter for inactivity, which is established based on a risk assessment and operational requirements. If during this period no user activity is detected, the session management system triggers an automatic logoff procedure.This procedure involves closing all active processes initiated by the user's session while preserving any processes specifically designated by the user to continue post-session. The termination process ensures that no residual authentication tokens or session identifiers remain active within the system, thereby preventing unauthorized reuse.DevOps management activities include regular reviews and updates of the inactivity parameters to align with evolving threat landscapes and ACME policies. Additionally, these activities involve conducting automated testing to validate that the session termination feature functions as expected. This testing simulates user inactivity for the specified period and verifies that the system appropriately terminates the session.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a Virtual Private Network (VPN) is established within Azure Virtual Networks (VNets). This VPN serves as a secure communication tunnel for remote access sessions, ensuring that data transmitted between the user and the cloud services is encrypted and inaccessible to unauthorized entities.The initial step involves configuring the VPN within Azure VNets, where specific parameters are set to enforce strong encryption standards. The VPN setup includes defining security policies that dictate the acceptable encryption methods, such as AES 256-bit encryption, and authentication protocols like SHA-256 for hashing.Following the configuration of the VPN, access control lists (ACLs) are implemented to restrict access to authorized users only. These ACLs are maintained and regularly updated in accordance with the organization's access policy, ensuring that only authenticated and authorized users can establish remote connections.In addition to the VPN, Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocols are employed for sessions that require end-to-end security. TLS configurations are applied to protect data in transit over the internet or other networks. This includes setting up appropriate certificates, managing cipher suites, and enforcing protocol versions that meet or exceed industry standards for secure communications.DevOps management activities play a crucial role in maintaining the security posture of the remote access environment. Automated deployment scripts are utilized to ensure consistent application of security settings across all VNets. Regular updates and patches are applied to VPN and TLS components to address known vulnerabilities.Security monitoring tools are integrated into the cloud infrastructure to detect any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts. These tools generate alerts that trigger incident response procedures, allowing for swift remediation of potential security incidents.Finally, periodic reviews and audits of the remote access infrastructure are conducted. These reviews assess compliance with organizational policies and regulatory requirements, ensuring that all security measures remain effective and up-to-date.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, the following step-by-step approach is implemented:1. Azure Networks (Virtual Networks or VNets) are configured to create a secure boundary around the cloud resources. VNets serve as the first layer of defense by segmenting the network and providing a controlled environment for resources to operate.2. Within these VNets, Azure Network Security Groups (NSGs) are established to act as firewalls that control inbound and outbound traffic to network interfaces, VMs, and subnets. NSG rules are meticulously reviewed and updated regularly to ensure that only authorized remote access is permitted. This aligns with the Trusted Internet Connections (TIC) initiative by limiting the number of access points and reducing attack surfaces.3. Remote access policies are enforced through Microsoft InTune and Microsoft Endpoint Manager, which provide centralized management of devices that connect to the cloud environment. These tools allow for the creation of comprehensive device management policies that dictate how devices should be managed when accessing the network remotely.4. Policies set within InTune and Endpoint Manager mandate that all remote connections must pass through managed network access control points, ensuring consistent enforcement of security protocols across all devices.5. Continuous monitoring mechanisms are put in place to validate compliance with the established remote access policies. Automated tools integrated with InTune and Endpoint Manager facilitate real-time policy enforcement and reporting, allowing for swift identification and remediation of non-compliant scenarios.6. Regular assessments are conducted manually to review NSG configurations against predefined security baselines to ensure that any changes in the network topology or business requirements do not introduce vulnerabilities or unauthorized access points.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats associated with the use of organization-controlled portable storage devices on external systems, a comprehensive approach integrating Azure Information Protection (AIP), Azure Sentinel, and Microsoft Endpoint Manager is employed. AIP classifies and protects documents and emails by applying labels that enforce protective actions if sensitive information is detected. Policies are configured within AIP to prevent classified data from being transferred onto portable storage devices unless specific encryption and access conditions are met.Azure Sentinel provides advanced threat detection capabilities. It monitors activities across the cloud environment, including the use of portable storage devices. By setting up analytics rules in Sentinel, any unauthorized attempt to use such devices on external systems triggers alerts. These alerts are then investigated by security personnel to ensure immediate response to potential breaches or policy violations.Microsoft Endpoint Manager plays a crucial role in managing and securing endpoints, including enforcing device compliance policies. Through its configuration profiles, the use of portable storage devices can be restricted or allowed based on compliance status, user roles, and other conditions defined by the organization's security policy.Azure DDoS Protection, along with Azure Networks (VNets) and Network Security Groups (NSGs), ensures secure network configurations that limit connectivity options for portable storage devices. NSGs are used to control inbound and outbound traffic to network interfaces (NIC), VMs, and subnets, which can be configured to deny any traffic related to portable storage device usage on external systems.Access controls are implemented through secure configuration management practices. This includes regularly updating network configurations in line with security best practices to prevent unauthorized access or data exfiltration via portable storage devices.Device usage is continuously monitored, with automated testing tools verifying the effectiveness of these restrictions. Any deviations from the expected state trigger automated responses or alerts for further investigation.

by-components.description: The system's infrastructure and application components are safeguarded from insider threats through a series of coordinated security measures and management activities. Initially, the Human Resources (HR) department implements an Insider Threat Awareness Training program, designed to educate employees about recognizing behaviors and activities that may signal an insider threat, such as unauthorized attempts to access data or unexplained wealth.This training is integrated into the onboarding process for new hires and is also part of regular refresher courses for all staff. The training content is tailored to different roles within ACME, ensuring relevance and effectiveness. For instance, managerial training emphasizes identifying behavioral changes in team members, while general employee training focuses on broader observation skills.Concurrently, the Security Awareness team develops a comprehensive Insider Threat Reporting Process Training. This training instructs personnel on the appropriate channels and procedures for reporting suspicious activities. It ensures that employees understand their responsibility in safeguarding ACME's assets and know how to report incidents securely and confidentially.Both training programs are supported by written policies and standard operating procedures (SOPs), which detail the steps to be taken when an insider threat is suspected. These documents are readily accessible to all employees through ACME's intranet or a dedicated security portal.To verify the effectiveness of these trainings, the HR Training Program tracks completion rates and comprehension through assessments following each session. Additionally, the Security Awareness Program employs automated tools to simulate scenarios that test whether employees can correctly navigate the reporting process. These simulations provide quantitative data on the workforce's readiness to respond to potential insider threats.
ACME System

by-components.description: The mitigation of threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components from social engineering and social mining begins with comprehensive literacy training for all employees. This training equips personnel with the knowledge to recognize and respond appropriately to various social engineering tactics such as phishing, pretexting, impersonation, and others.Firstly, a structured training program is developed and implemented, focusing on the recognition of social engineering attempts. During these sessions, employees are educated on the different types of social engineering attacks, the risks associated with them, and the indicators that may suggest a social engineering attempt is taking place. Practical examples and simulations are used to reinforce learning and ensure understanding.Following the recognition training, employees are instructed on the proper procedures for reporting suspected social engineering incidents. Clear guidelines are provided on how to communicate concerns through organizational channels. The reporting process is designed to be straightforward and accessible to encourage prompt and accurate reporting of security incidents.To support these activities, security incident reporting procedures are established and maintained. These procedures outline the steps an employee should take when they suspect or identify a social engineering attempt. They include immediate actions to contain and assess the situation as well as longer-term measures for incident resolution and post-incident analysis.In parallel with training initiatives, logs of security incidents are meticulously kept. These logs serve as a record of all reported incidents, detailing the nature of the incident, how it was handled, and any follow-up actions taken. Regular log analysis is conducted to identify patterns or repeated attempts at social engineering, allowing for continuous improvement of both preventive measures and response strategies.All training sessions are documented with records maintained for each employee's participation. This documentation serves as evidence of compliance with literacy training requirements and allows for verification that all personnel have received appropriate instruction.To ensure ongoing effectiveness, a defined process implemented by ACME is periodically reviewed and updated based on emerging threats, lessons learned from past incidents, and feedback from employees. Continuous improvement is integral to maintaining robust defenses against social engineering and social mining threats.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a robust audit and monitoring strategy is implemented using a defined process implemented by ACME as the primary security information and event management (SIEM) platform. The following steps outline the mitigation process:1. Data Collection: A defined process implemented by ACME is configured to collect audit logs from all relevant system and application components within the cloud environment. This includes logs from virtual machines, databases, network devices, and applications.2. Log Processing: The collected logs are processed to standardize their format, making them suitable for analysis. This ensures that data from various sources can be correlated and analyzed cohesively.3. Event Definition: Specific criteria for events of interest are established based on organizational requirements. These criteria include but are not limited to system resources involved, accessed information objects, user identities, types of events, locations within the network, timestamps, IP addresses, and the success or failure of events.4. Alert Configuration: Using the defined event criteria, alerts are configured within a defined process implemented by ACME to notify security personnel of potential security incidents. These alerts are fine-tuned to reduce false positives while ensuring true threats are promptly identified.5. Continuous Monitoring: A defined process implemented by ACME actively monitors the cloud environment in real-time, applying the defined event criteria to audit records as they are ingested. This enables immediate detection of potential threats.6. Search Capability: Security analysts have access to search and query tools within a defined process implemented by ACME that allow them to filter and sort audit records based on the established event criteria. This facilitates rapid investigation and response to incidents.7. Analysis and Response: When an alert is triggered, security analysts review the corresponding audit records to determine the nature of the event. If a threat is confirmed, incident response procedures are initiated according to predefined protocols.8. Reporting and Compliance: Regular reports are generated from a defined process implemented by ACME that detail audit findings and incident response activities. These reports serve both internal review purposes and compliance with FedRAMP requirements.9. Review and Update: The effectiveness of the audit monitoring strategy is regularly reviewed, and updates are made to event criteria, alert configurations, and response procedures as needed to adapt to evolving threats.
ACME System

by-components.description: ACME, a FedRAMP accredited 3PAO, is engaged to evaluate the security posture of cloud system infrastructure and application components. These assessors, who have no conflict of interest with the system's development or management, conduct thorough assessments to ensure that security controls are effectively mitigating threats. The assessment process is initiated by authorizing officials who determine the necessary level of independence based on the system's security category and associated risks.The selected independent assessors, either internal entities with the requisite distance from system operations or external third-party entities, are not involved in any aspect of system development or management. This separation ensures their objectivity and the credibility of their findings. They do not assess their own work nor act as advocates for the organization, which further reinforces their impartiality.During the assessment process, these teams scrutinize security components such as firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and encryption protocols, as well as DevOps management activities which include "a defined process implemented by ACME". Their analysis includes a review of how these components and activities are implemented to safeguard against potential threats.If the organization owning the systems is small or structured in a way that necessitates internal individuals conducting assessments, additional measures are taken to maintain independence. In such cases, results from internal assessments are subjected to rigorous validation by separate teams of experts unaffiliated with the system's operational chain. These experts critically review assessment outcomes to confirm their accuracy and reliability.The independent assessment team documents their findings, providing evidence that security measures are correctly implemented and functioning as intended. This documentation is then used by authorizing officials to make informed risk-based decisions regarding the system's authorization to operate.
ACME System

This includes examining contracts, statements of work, and other relevant materials that detail the relationship between the assessors and the organization.3. Verification of Impartiality: The impartiality of the assessors is verified through interviews and background checks to ensure there are no conflicts of interest that could compromise the integrity of the assessment.4. Continuous Monitoring Strategy Development: A strategy is developed that outlines how continuous monitoring will be performed. This includes defining roles and responsibilities, frequency of assessments, methodologies to be used, reporting procedures, and response actions for identified issues.5. Assessment Execution: The independent assessors conduct assessments according to the continuous monitoring strategy. They evaluate security controls, infrastructure components, and application components against predefined security capabilities.6. Reporting and Analysis: Findings from the assessments are documented in reports that provide an objective analysis of the security posture of the cloud system. These reports highlight any vulnerabilities or deficiencies and recommend corrective actions.7. Response Actions: Based on the assessment reports, response actions are taken to address any identified issues. This may involve adjusting security controls, updating policies, or implementing additional protective measures.8. Continuous Improvement: The continuous monitoring strategy is reviewed regularly to incorporate lessons learned from assessments and evolving threat landscapes. Adjustments are made to ensure that the strategy remains effective in mitigating threats to the system's infrastructure and application components.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a comprehensive penetration testing program is established. This program involves a sequence of activities that are designed to identify and address vulnerabilities which could be exploited by adversaries.Initially, a pretest analysis is conducted, leveraging full knowledge of the system to identify potential vulnerabilities. This analysis includes reviewing existing vulnerability assessments and utilizing their findings to inform the penetration test planning. The scope of the penetration testing encompasses Azure Virtual Networks, Azure VMs, Web App Services, SQL servers, Load Balancers, and App Service Environments.The penetration testing is performed at a predefined frequency as per organizational policy to ensure timely identification of new or previously undetected vulnerabilities. The frequency is determined based on risk assessments that consider factors such as the criticality of the system components, threat intelligence, and historical incident data.Specialized agents or teams with technical expertise in network, operating system, and application security are tasked with conducting the penetration tests. These individuals possess the necessary skills to simulate adversarial actions effectively and have clear rules of engagement that align with anticipated adversary behaviors.During the penetration testing process, both physical and technical controls are exercised to determine the exploitability of identified vulnerabilities. This includes attempting to bypass security features and exploit weaknesses in infrastructure components and security features.Upon completion of the penetration tests, findings are documented and analyzed. Identified vulnerabilities are prioritized for remediation based on their potential impact and likelihood of exploitation. Remediation activities are then executed according to an established timeline.Throughout this process, all sensitive information uncovered during testing is protected in accordance with laws, regulations, and organizational policies. Expectations for handling such information are clearly communicated through rules of engagement, contracts, or other appropriate mechanisms.The results from these penetration tests are used to refine security measures and inform continuous monitoring activities within the DevOps pipelines. This ensures that security is integrated into the development lifecycle and that changes in the system's threat landscape are promptly addressed.
ACME System

by-components.description: ACME is engaged to evaluate the security posture of the cloud system's infrastructure and application components. The engagement begins with the verification of the credentials and authorization of the penetration testing personnel to ensure they are qualified and have no conflicts of interest related to the system's development, operation, or management.The penetration testing schedule is established in alignment with organizational risk management policies, ensuring that testing occurs at a frequency that reflects the system's risk level and operational tempo. Before testing commences, a clear scope is defined, which includes identifying critical system components and security features that will be examined. This scoping ensures comprehensive coverage of potential vulnerabilities within the system's infrastructure, including network devices, servers, and applications.During the penetration testing activities, testers employ a variety of tools and techniques to simulate real-world attacks on both infrastructure components such as firewalls, routers, and switches, as well as application components including web services and databases. These activities are designed to identify weaknesses that could be exploited by malicious actors.Security components integrated into the system play a crucial role in mitigating threats during these tests. Intrusion detection systems (IDS), firewalls, and security information and event management (SIEM) systems provide real-time monitoring and alerting for any suspicious activities. Additionally, configuration management databases (CMDBs) ensure that all system components are accounted for and configured according to security best practices.DevOps management activities complement these security measures by incorporating security into the software development lifecycle (SDLC). Through a defined process implemented by ACME, code is regularly scanned for vulnerabilities, and automated testing ensures that security controls are functioning as intended.Upon completion of penetration tests, detailed reports are generated that outline discovered vulnerabilities, their potential impact on the system, and recommendations for remediation. These reports are reviewed by relevant stakeholders including security analysts and system owners to prioritize and address findings in a timely manner.The results of these activities feed back into the organization's overall risk management process. Remediation actions are tracked until resolution, ensuring that identified vulnerabilities are addressed. Lessons learned from each round of testing inform future security practices and penetration test planning.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a comprehensive security strategy is implemented. Security components are integrated into the system architecture to provide robust defense mechanisms. These include firewalls, intrusion detection systems (IDS), and intrusion prevention systems (IPS) that monitor and control incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules.DevOps management activities play a crucial role in maintaining the security posture of the cloud system. Through a defined process implemented by ACME, security checks are embedded within the development process. Automated scanning tools are employed to detect vulnerabilities in code before deployment.Regularly scheduled vulnerability assessments are conducted to identify and remediate weaknesses within the system. Patch management procedures ensure that all software components are up-to-date with the latest security patches.Access controls are enforced through identity and access management (IAM) solutions, which authenticate and authorize user access to system resources. Multi-factor authentication (MFA) adds an additional layer of security by requiring multiple forms of verification.Data encryption is utilized both at rest and in transit to protect sensitive information from unauthorized access or interception. Encryption keys are managed securely, with strict policies governing their use and storage.Security incident and event management (SIEM) systems aggregate and analyze log data from various sources within the cloud environment to detect potential security incidents. In the event of an incident, predefined incident response protocols are activated to contain, eradicate, and recover from the threat.Red team exercises simulate real-world attacks on the system to evaluate the effectiveness of existing security measures. These exercises involve both technology-based attacks and social engineering tactics. The findings from these exercises inform enhancements to security training programs and adjustments to control implementations for improved resilience against cyber threats.All these measures are documented in policies and standard operating procedures (SOPs), ensuring that all personnel understand their roles and responsibilities in maintaining the system's security. Regular training sessions keep staff informed about current cyber threats and defensive strategies.

by-components.description: The system implements a robust version control mechanism that is integral to the configuration management process. This mechanism ensures that all hardware, software, firmware, configuration files, and records, along with their associated documentation, are maintained in a state that supports rollback capabilities. To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, the following steps are taken:1. Version Control Repository: A centralized version control repository is established to store baseline configurations of all system components. This repository is secured with access controls to prevent unauthorized modifications.2. Baseline Configuration Documentation: Each component's baseline configuration is documented thoroughly, including hardware specifications, software versions, firmware levels, and configuration settings. This documentation is stored alongside the configurations in the version control repository.3. Change Management Procedures: Standard operating procedures (SOPs) for change management are developed and followed. These procedures include steps for reviewing, testing, approving, and documenting changes to the system components.4. Automated Rollback Tools: Tools capable of automating the rollback process are implemented. These tools can revert system components to their previous baseline configuration in case of an unsuccessful update or detected vulnerability.5. Continuous Monitoring: The system employs continuous monitoring tools to detect deviations from the baseline configurations. Any anomalies trigger alerts and initiate a review process to determine if a rollback is necessary.6. Secure Access Controls: Access to the version control repository and rollback tools is restricted to authorized personnel only, based on their role within the organization. Multi-factor authentication and logging of access attempts ensure traceability and accountability.7. Training and Awareness: Personnel involved in configuration management are trained on the importance of maintaining baseline configurations and the procedures for executing rollbacks when required.8. Regular Audits: Periodic audits are conducted to verify that the baseline configurations stored in the repository match the actual state of system components. Discrepancies are addressed immediately through a defined process implemented by ACME.
ACME System

by-components.description: The mitigation of threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components through security components and DevOps management activities is executed as follows:1. **Change Testing**: Prior to finalizing any changes, Azure DevOps Pipelines are utilized to execute test scripts. This ensures that modifications to hardware, software, or firmware components do not negatively impact system operations. Veracode and Zscaler are integrated within this pipeline to automatically assess the security posture of the changes, identifying potential vulnerabilities or misconfigurations.2. **Security Log Review**: Concurrent with change testing, Microsoft Defender for Endpoints continuously monitors for any security breaches. The logs from this tool are reviewed to confirm that the testing phase has not introduced new security risks. This step is crucial in understanding the implications of changes on the system's security and privacy policies.3. **Change Validation**: Once testing is complete, Azure Web Application Firewalls (WAF) and Azure DNS settings undergo validation tests. These tests ensure that changes align with established security policies and do not introduce new vulnerabilities. ACME Fortify serves as a repository for validation results, providing an audit trail for compliance documentation.4. **Change Documentation**: All changes are meticulously documented through Microsoft Teams conversations and FreshService tickets. This documentation provides a clear record of system modifications, facilitating traceability and accountability. Vanta compliance automation tools are employed to review the completeness of this documentation, ensuring that every change is captured accurately and in full detail.5. **Compliance Automation Reports**: Vanta generates reports that confirm all changes have been documented appropriately. These reports serve as evidence for auditors that the organization maintains a comprehensive record of system modifications.6. **Scheduled Downtime**: If operational systems need to be taken offline for testing, such activities are scheduled during planned system outages whenever possible to minimize disruption to organizational mission and business functions.7. **Compensating Controls**: In instances where testing cannot be conducted on operational systems, compensating controls are employed to mitigate any risks associated with the changes being tested.

by-components.description: Access to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components is strictly regulated to mitigate threats. Physical access restrictions are clearly defined and documented within the access control policies, and these policies are fortified by robust physical security measures. The change management process requires that any proposed changes undergo a thorough review, ensuring only approved modifications are implemented. This process is reinforced by maintaining meticulous records of approvals.Enforcement of physical access restrictions is automated through access control systems, which prevent unauthorized individuals from physically initiating system changes. Similarly, logical access restrictions are well-defined within the logical security measures and are integrated into the change management process for consistency and accountability.The enforcement of logical access controls is also automated, preventing unauthorized software or firmware changes. Access control systems verify credentials and permissions before granting the ability to alter system components or operational procedures.Security capabilities such as workflow automation contribute to a secure change management environment by standardizing processes and reducing human error. Software libraries are managed to ensure that only authorized and validated code is used in the system. Media libraries are similarly protected to prevent unauthorized access to storage media containing sensitive information.Changes are implemented through a defined process implemented by ACME whenever possible, minimizing direct interaction with the system and reducing the risk of unauthorized alterations. Additionally, change windows are established so that updates occur during designated times, allowing for heightened vigilance and reduced operational disruption.

by-components.description: The configuration settings for the system's infrastructure and application components are managed through a suite of automated tools, which are integral to maintaining the security posture of the cloud environment. These tools are selected based on their ability to enforce and maintain the desired configuration states as defined by organizational policies and standards.Firstly, hardening tools are deployed to ensure that all infrastructure components adhere to the stringent baseline configurations established by ACME. These tools systematically remove unnecessary functions and services, thereby reducing potential vulnerabilities. The use of such tools is scheduled, and their execution is logged to provide an auditable trail of compliance.Secondly, baseline configuration tools are utilized to apply standard configurations across all applicable components. These tools are integrated into DevOps pipelines to ensure that any new deployment or update adheres to the required configuration settings. This integration enables real-time application of configurations during the deployment process, minimizing the window of opportunity for misconfigurations to occur.In addition to managing and applying configurations, these automated tools also play a critical role in the continuous monitoring of the system. They provide alerting mechanisms and dashboards that facilitate risk-based decision-making by offering a consolidated view of the system's configuration state. Any deviations from the desired state trigger alerts, prompting immediate investigation and remediation actions.Security monitoring and validation tools are employed to verify that the applied configuration settings align with ACME's requirements. These tools continuously scan the environment, comparing actual configurations against approved baselines. Discrepancies are logged, and reports are generated to document compliance status.Furthermore, all changes to configuration settings are documented in a change management system, providing traceability from request initiation through approval to implementation. This documentation supports accountability and enables review during audits or investigations.To ensure effectiveness, these processes are overseen by personnel with specific roles and responsibilities defined within policies and standard operating procedures (SOPs). Regular training is conducted to maintain proficiency in using these tools and executing associated activities. Compliance with these practices is mandatory and subject to periodic internal reviews and external audits as part of ongoing risk management efforts.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a multi-layered approach is employed, leveraging security components and DevOps management activities. The following steps outline the mitigation process:1. Auto-execute features are disabled across all Azure Web App Services and Azure Virtual Networks (VNets) to prevent unauthorized program execution. This is achieved by configuring service settings and policies within the Azure platform to ensure that no software can run without explicit authorization.2. A whitelist of approved software programs is maintained and enforced through Azure DevOps Pipelines. Only software that has been vetted and approved by ACME is allowed to be deployed and executed within the cloud environment.3. Microsoft Defender for Endpoints is configured with organizational policies that restrict program execution. This includes setting up rules for threat and vulnerability management, ensuring that any attempt to execute unauthorized software is blocked and alerts are generated for further investigation.4. On Azure Compute Virtual Machines and Azure SQL Servers, resource governance policies are implemented to limit the number of concurrent instances of any given program. This ensures compliance with organizational policies regarding resource usage and prevents potential performance degradation or system instability.5. Automated scripts are developed and deployed to continuously monitor and validate the actual state of program executions against the desired state. These scripts can detect deviations from policy, such as unauthorized programs running or too many instances of a program executing simultaneously.6. All security configurations, including auto-execute feature restrictions and instance execution limits, are documented in standard operating procedures (SOPs). These SOPs serve as a reference for ongoing maintenance and audits, ensuring consistent application of security measures.7. Regular manual reviews are conducted to assess the effectiveness of the implemented security measures. During these reviews, system settings and logs are examined to verify compliance with the desired state specifications outlined in the test cases.

Azure Sentinel applies advanced analytics to this data to identify potential threats or anomalies indicative of privacy control failures or security breaches.In parallel, Microsoft Defender for Endpoints is utilized to reinforce endpoint security. This tool performs ongoing threat and vulnerability management by identifying, assessing, and prioritizing vulnerabilities as well as misconfigurations on endpoints. By doing so, it provides proactive risk management and ensures that protection controls are in place and functioning correctly.For each cloud infrastructure component such as Azure DNS, Azure Monitor, Storage, SQL Server, Application Service Environments (ASE), Web App Services, CDN, Compute Virtual Machine, DevOps, Key Vault, and DDoS Protection, configurations and logs are automatically retrieved. This retrieval process is facilitated by Azure's native capabilities or via integration with third-party automation tools where necessary.These logs and configuration settings are then scrutinized to confirm the presence of organizational information protection controls. The automated tools check against predefined desired state specifications to ensure that all components adhere to the required security posture.The assessment process is automated to minimize human error and expedite the verification process. Any discrepancies between the actual state and the desired state trigger alerts. These alerts initiate remediation workflows which are also automated where possible. The remediation tasks include patching vulnerabilities, adjusting configurations to meet standards, or escalating issues to appropriate personnel for further action.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure components and application components, a comprehensive approach is adopted, integrating security components with DevOps management activities. This begins with the identification of critical assets through criticality analysis, business continuity planning, or business impact analyses. These assets are categorized based on their importance to mission-critical functions and the potential impact of their compromise.Security measures are then tailored to protect these critical assets. This includes the deployment of advanced security mechanisms such as firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and encryption protocols that are specifically configured to safeguard sensitive data and operations. Access controls are enforced strictly, ensuring that only authorized personnel have access to critical assets, and multi-factor authentication is implemented to provide an additional layer of security.DevOps management activities play a crucial role in maintaining a secure environment. Continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines are designed with security in mind, incorporating automated security testing at every stage of development to identify and remediate vulnerabilities early. Configuration management tools ensure that all infrastructure components are consistently deployed according to hardened baselines, reducing the attack surface.Regular vulnerability assessments and penetration tests are conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of the security measures in place. These activities help in identifying any weaknesses that could be exploited by adversaries and allow for timely corrective actions.In case of an incident, incident response plans are activated, which include predefined procedures for containment, eradication, recovery, and post-incident analysis. These plans are regularly tested through tabletop exercises and drills involving both technical personnel and decision-makers to ensure readiness.Documentation is maintained meticulously throughout the process, providing clear records of all security measures implemented, tests conducted, and incidents managed. This documentation serves as evidence for compliance with FedRAMP requirements and supports continuous monitoring efforts.

by-components.description: The mitigation of threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components involves a systematic approach that integrates security components and DevOps management activities within the context of contingency planning. The following steps outline this process:1. **Identification of Critical Components**: The first step is to identify all critical infrastructure and application components that support essential functions. This includes servers, storage, network devices, and key software applications.2. **Development of Contingency Plans**: For each identified component, specific contingency plans such as Business Continuity Plans (BCP), Disaster Recovery Plans (DRP), and Continuity of Operations Plans (COOP) are developed. These plans detail the actions to be taken in response to various threat scenarios.3. **Integration with Security Capabilities**: Security capabilities like firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and data encryption are incorporated into the contingency planning to ensure that security controls remain effective during disruptions.4. **DevOps Involvement**: DevOps teams are engaged in the contingency planning process to ensure that development and operational practices include resilience features such as automated backups, failover procedures, and infrastructure as code for rapid re-deployment.5. **Coordination Across Plans**: Coordination meetings are held between the teams responsible for BCP, DRP, COOP, Crisis Communications, Critical Infrastructure Protection, Cyber Incident Response, and Occupant Emergency Plans to ensure alignment and interoperability of plans.6. **Testing and Exercises**: Regular testing exercises are conducted to validate the effectiveness of the contingency plans and the ability of the infrastructure to recover from disruptions. These exercises also involve testing the security components' functionality during simulated incidents.7. **Documentation and Reporting**: All tests and exercises are thoroughly documented, including any lessons learned or improvements identified. This documentation is shared with relevant stakeholders to maintain transparency and accountability.8. **Continuous Improvement**: Feedback from testing exercises is used to refine and update contingency plans regularly. This ensures that the plans evolve in line with changes in the threat landscape and technological advancements.9. **Communication Protocols**: Clear communication protocols are established so that in the event of an incident, all stakeholders are informed promptly according to their roles in the contingency plans.10. **Training**: Personnel involved in implementing contingency plans receive regular training on their roles and responsibilities within these plans to ensure readiness when actual incidents occur.
ACME System

by-components.description: The mitigation of threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components begins with the identification of an alternate storage site that is geographically separate from the primary storage site. This separation is critical to reduce susceptibility to the same threats, such as natural disasters or structural failures. The alternate site is chosen based on a thorough organizational risk assessment that considers various potential threats.Azure Storage is utilized as the alternate site, leveraging its inherent capabilities for redundancy and resiliency. Azure BLOB Storage Bucket Permissions are configured to ensure that only authorized personnel have access to the data stored within, thereby mitigating the risk of unauthorized access or hostile attacks.In addition, Azure DDoS Protection is employed to safeguard both the primary and alternate sites against Distributed Denial of Service attacks. This protection is crucial in maintaining availability and accessibility of the storage sites, particularly during an incident where the primary site might be compromised.The Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP) plays a pivotal role in outlining the procedures for failover to the alternate site. This plan is meticulously documented and includes detailed steps for activating the alternate site in case of a disaster. It also specifies roles and responsibilities for personnel during such events, ensuring clarity and efficiency in response efforts.DevOps management activities include regular testing of the failover procedures to ensure they are effective and can be executed smoothly in an actual disaster scenario. These tests are conducted as per predefined schedules and are documented for future reference and improvement.Storage Configuration Management ensures that any changes to storage infrastructure, whether at the primary or alternate site, are tracked and managed systematically. This activity reduces errors of omission or commission by providing a clear audit trail of modifications and their impact on system resilience.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components caused by area-wide disruptions, the following steps are implemented:1. Access logs for alternate storage sites, such as Azure Storage and Azure Backup, are enabled to ensure visibility into accessibility issues. These logs provide real-time data on access patterns and potential disruptions, allowing for prompt detection of problems.2. The disaster recovery plan includes a comprehensive list of explicit mitigation actions to address accessibility problems to alternate storage sites. This ensures that there is a predetermined course of action to follow in the event of an area-wide disruption.3. Regular testing of access to alternate storage sites is conducted to validate connectivity and the effectiveness of mitigation strategies. This ensures that backup data can be accessed when primary systems are unavailable.4. Alternate storage sites are geographically dispersed to avoid single points of failure due to localized events. This geographic diversity increases resilience against area-wide disruptions.5. Data backups are duplicated across multiple alternate sites, providing redundancy and ensuring that if one site becomes inaccessible, others remain available for data retrieval.6. Provisions for physical access to retrieve backup information are outlined in case electronic access to alternate sites is disrupted. This includes secure transportation means and authorized personnel who can access these sites.7. Continuous monitoring is in place to detect early signs of area-wide disruptions, allowing for preemptive activation of disaster recovery protocols before the primary systems are affected.8. Clear communication channels are established to coordinate with stakeholders, including cloud service providers and emergency response teams, during an area-wide disruption.9. Training programs for personnel are conducted regularly, ensuring that all individuals involved understand their roles and responsibilities in executing the disaster recovery plan.10. Regular updates to the disaster recovery plan reflect new threats, technological changes, and lessons learned from drills and actual incidents, maintaining the plan's relevance and effectiveness.
ACME System

by-components.description: The mitigation of threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components through security components and DevOps management activities begins with the establishment of alternate processing site agreements that include priority-of-service provisions. These provisions are negotiated to align with ACME's availability requirements and recovery time objectives as part of a comprehensive contingency planning effort.Firstly, the business continuity plan is updated to reflect the necessity for priority-of-service in alternate processing site agreements, ensuring that ACME receives expedited service restoration in the event of a disruption. This plan is crafted in collaboration with stakeholders and subject matter experts to identify critical services and establish appropriate recovery time objectives.Next, contract management personnel engage with service providers to negotiate terms that guarantee priority-of-service. These terms are documented within contractual agreements which are then reviewed by legal teams to ensure enforceability and compliance with ACME policies.Following the establishment of these agreements, a review process is implemented where existing agreements and relevant documentation are periodically examined to confirm that priority-of-service provisions remain current and effective. This involves a manual review by designated personnel who assess whether the actual state of the agreements meets the desired state specifications outlined in the business continuity plan.In parallel, DevOps management activities incorporate these priority-of-service provisions into their operational workflows. This includes configuring automated failover mechanisms, monitoring tools, and incident response protocols that leverage the agreed-upon priority services from vendors during an outage or disruption.Additionally, training programs are conducted for staff responsible for activating and managing alternate processing sites to ensure they understand how to invoke priority services swiftly and effectively. These training sessions cover procedures for escalating incidents to service providers and coordinating with them under the terms of the priority-of-service agreements.Finally, exercises simulating disruptions are periodically conducted to validate that the alternate processing capabilities can be activated within the established recovery time objectives. The results from these exercises are documented, and any identified gaps or weaknesses lead to adjustments in both contractual agreements and operational practices to enhance resilience against threats.

by-components.description: The mitigation of threats to the cloud system's infrastructure components and application components involves a series of orchestrated security components and DevOps management activities. The process begins with the deployment of a defined process implemented by ACME, which are tasked with creating secure and reliable copies of data as part of the backup operations.Firstly, a defined process implemented by ACME is configured to automatically back up critical data at predefined intervals. This ensures that, in the event of data loss or corruption, there is a recent copy available for recovery. The reliability of the backup media is verified through automated tests that simulate retrieval operations. These tests involve decrypting and transporting a random sample of backup files from the storage location to validate that they can be restored accurately and completely.Secondly, a defined process implemented by ACME is utilized to continuously monitor the integrity of backup information. Data integrity monitoring is an essential activity that involves implementing checks and balances to detect any unauthorized changes or corruption in the backed-up data. This activity is conducted manually, with personnel responsible for reviewing alerts and reports generated by these tools to ensure that the integrity of the backup information remains intact.In addition to these specific activities, there are overarching policies and standard operating procedures (SOPs) in place that govern the frequency of backups, the retention period of backup data, and the roles and responsibilities of personnel involved in backup operations. These policies ensure that all actions taken are consistent with organizational requirements and compliance standards.Furthermore, regular drills and exercises are conducted to train staff on the correct procedures for restoring data from backups. This training ensures that, in an actual disaster recovery scenario, personnel are well-prepared to execute restoration activities quickly and effectively.Each step in this process is documented, with logs and reports generated to provide an audit trail for review by internal auditors or external entities such as FedRAMP assessors. This documentation serves as evidence that backup information can be reliably retrieved and that both the systems where the information is stored and the operations used to retrieve it are functioning correctly.

by-components.description: The system infrastructure employs Azure Storage for the storage of backup information, ensuring that all backup data is encrypted at rest using cryptographic mechanisms. The encryption process is integrated into the storage service, which automatically encrypts the data before it is stored and decrypts it upon retrieval, using encryption keys managed by Azure Key Vault. This ensures confidentiality and integrity of the backup information in accordance with its security category.Azure Key Vault is utilized for cryptographic key management, providing a centralized process for managing encryption keys. It includes capabilities such as key rotation, which is performed in accordance with defined policies and procedures to mitigate the risk of key compromise. The key rotation activity is conducted manually, following a schedule that aligns with best practices and regulatory requirements.To verify the proper implementation of cryptographic protections, automated tools are used to check the encryption status of data within Azure Storage. These tools provide continuous monitoring to ensure that encryption is consistently applied to all backup data.For key management verification, a manual assessment process is established where designated personnel periodically review the key rotation logs and activities within Azure Key Vault. This review ensures that key rotation occurs as planned and that any issues are identified and addressed promptly.

by-components.description: The mitigation of threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components is achieved through a series of orchestrated activities that align with ACME's contingency plan. Initially, in the event of a disruption, compromise, or failure, the designated response team initiates the recovery process within the predefined time period consistent with the established recovery time objectives (RTO). This involves executing documented contingency plan activities, which include identifying and isolating affected components, restoring operations from backups, and ensuring that critical services are brought back online to achieve a known state.Following recovery, reconstitution activities commence within the time period stipulated by the recovery point objectives (RPO). During this phase, interim system capabilities that were activated to maintain essential functions are carefully deactivated. The team conducts a thorough assessment of the restored system capabilities to confirm their integrity and functionality. This includes verifying that security features are fully operational and that all patches and updates have been applied.Continuous monitoring activities are then reestablished to ensure ongoing vigilance against potential threats. This involves reinstating automated tools and a defined process implemented by ACME designed to detect anomalies and security incidents. The system may undergo reauthorization if required, ensuring that it continues to meet the stringent security standards expected for cloud systems under FedRAMP.
ACME System

by-components.description: Transaction recovery mechanisms are integral to maintaining the integrity and availability of data within cloud systems. For database management systems and transaction processing systems, which are critical transaction-based systems, the implementation of transaction rollback and journaling is essential.The system infrastructure components, including servers and storage devices, are configured to support these mechanisms. The security components, such as database software with built-in rollback capabilities and journaling features, are properly installed and maintained.DevOps management activities play a pivotal role in ensuring that these mechanisms function correctly. These activities include regular system configuration reviews to confirm that transaction rollback features are enabled and appropriately configured. Additionally, data management procedures ensure that journaling mechanisms are operational, capturing every transaction accurately for potential recovery needs.To mitigate threats effectively, the following steps are taken:1. Database Management Systems (DBMS) are equipped with transaction rollback capabilities. This feature allows the system to revert back to a known good state in case of a process failure or an identified threat that compromises data integrity.2. Transaction Processing Systems (TPS) utilize journaling methods to maintain a log of all transactions. In the event of a failure or security incident, this log facilitates the restoration of affected transactions up to the point of failure.3. Regular automated testing is conducted to verify the functionality of rollback and journaling mechanisms. This ensures that in practice, the system can recover from failures as designed.4. System configurations and related security settings are documented and reviewed periodically to ensure ongoing compliance with established policies and procedures.5. DevOps teams receive training on how to respond to incidents involving transaction failures, including the execution of recovery processes using a defined process implemented by ACME.
