by-components.description: Azure Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) roles are established to ensure that each organizational user is uniquely identified and authenticated. These roles are integral to the user authentication process, ensuring that access is granted according to the defined policies and permissions associated with each role. When a user attempts to access a resource or perform an action, Azure RBAC checks the user's assigned role against the permissions required for the requested operation.The authentication process is reinforced by automated API calls that verify the user authentication process. These calls are designed to confirm that authentication procedures are functioning as intended and that users are being correctly identified before being granted access. This automation provides a consistent and reliable means of enforcing identification and authentication policies across ACME's cloud environment.In addition to user authentication, Azure RBAC roles are also used to associate unique user identifications with a defined process implemented by ACME acting on behalf of users. This association ensures that activities performed by a defined process implemented by ACME can be traced back to the individual users who initiated them, providing accountability and facilitating auditability.To further support accountability, Azure Sentinel alert reviews are conducted regularly. During these reviews, process logs are examined manually to verify that actions taken by a defined process implemented by ACME on behalf of users are properly associated with their unique identifications. This activity serves as a check to ensure that the security capabilities implemented through Azure RBAC are effectively associating user identities with process actions, as required by policy.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a multi-factor authentication (MFA) strategy is employed for privileged accounts, leveraging Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) and Microsoft Endpoint Manager. The process begins with configuring MFA settings within Azure AD to enforce an additional layer of security for privileged users. This involves setting up policies that require not just a password (something the user knows), but also a second factor like a phone verification or hardware token (something the user has), or biometric verification (something the user is).Once the MFA requirements are established in Azure AD, attention turns to device management through Microsoft Endpoint Manager. Here, security management settings are adjusted to ensure that any device used by privileged accounts adheres to the MFA policy. This includes enforcing compliance policies that check for MFA at every sign-in attempt from any device attempting to access resources managed by Endpoint Manager.The implementation of these measures is verified through automated API calls to Azure AD, which confirm that MFA is enabled and functioning correctly for all privileged accounts. Additionally, manual checks of system logs within Microsoft Endpoint Manager provide assurance that devices are compliant with the MFA policy and that no privileged access occurs without proper authentication.

by-components.description: The mitigation of threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components through multi-factor authentication (MFA) is achieved by employing a combination of security components and DevOps management activities. The process begins with the configuration of Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) to enforce MFA for all non-privileged accounts.Firstly, Azure AD is configured to require MFA, ensuring that each user must provide at least two forms of authentication before being granted access. This typically involves something the user knows (like a password or PIN), something the user has (such as a phone or hardware token), and/or something the user is (biometric verification like a fingerprint or facial recognition).Next, policies are established within Azure AD to define the conditions under which MFA is triggered. These policies take into account factors such as user role, location, device compliance status, and risk level of the access attempt. Conditional Access policies are particularly useful in this context, allowing for granular control over when and how users are prompted for additional authentication factors.Once policies are in place, Azure AD's reporting features are utilized to monitor compliance with the MFA requirement. Regular reviews of authentication logs via API calls or through Microsoft Azure Sentinel are conducted to verify that MFA is being used consistently across all non-privileged accounts.Additionally, DevOps management activities include routine audits of Azure AD configurations and policies to ensure they align with current threat models and organizational security requirements. Any identified gaps or misconfigurations are addressed promptly to maintain the integrity of the MFA implementation.User education is also a key component of the strategy; users are trained on the importance of MFA and how to use it effectively. This includes instructions on setting up authentication methods and guidance on handling authentication prompts during sign-in attempts.In case of any changes in personnel or roles, procedures are in place for immediate updates to access rights and authentication requirements. This ensures that only authorized individuals have access to non-privileged accounts and that such access is protected by MFA at all times.

by-components.description: Individual user authentication is enforced through Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) before any access to shared accounts or resources is granted. The process begins with configuring Azure AD to require individual credentials from each user. Access policies are established to ensure that no shared account can be accessed without proper individual authentication. These policies are applied across the cloud infrastructure, ensuring consistent enforcement.Upon a user's attempt to access a shared resource, Azure AD prompts for their unique credentials. This step ensures that each user is authenticated individually and that their identity is verified before any further access is granted. The successful authentication event is then logged by Azure AD, creating an audit trail.The security logs generated by Azure AD are configured to capture detailed information about the authentication process, including timestamps, user identifiers, and the specific shared resources accessed. These logs are protected against unauthorized access and tampering to maintain their integrity.Regular automated assessments are conducted using tools integrated with Azure AD. These tools assess the authentication logs to verify that access to shared accounts or resources is consistently preceded by individual user authentication. Any deviations from the established policy are flagged for immediate investigation.In the event of an attempted unauthorized access, Azure AD's security features are designed to deny entry and log the attempt. Alerts are generated for security personnel to take appropriate action, ensuring that any potential security breach is addressed promptly.
ACME System

by-components.description: Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is configured to employ replay-resistant authentication mechanisms to mitigate threats associated with replay attacks. This is achieved through the use of CISA approved MFA factors (FIDO2 or Biometrics).The process begins when a user initiates an authentication request. Azure AD responds by issuing a nonce or challenge specific to that session. The user's credentials, along with the response to the nonce or challenge, are then submitted back to Azure AD. Azure AD verifies the response and, if correct, grants access to the user.To ensure this mechanism functions as intended, regular checks are conducted manually to validate that nonces or challenges are indeed being used and that they are unique for each session. These checks involve examining the authentication logs and settings within Azure AD to confirm that the system is adhering to the prescribed security capabilities.
ACME System

by-components.description: The cloud system has implemented a robust mechanism for mitigating threats associated with identity authentication by integrating Personal Identity Verification (PIV)-compliant credentials into both logical and physical access control systems.For logical access, the system incorporates a defined process implemented by ACME that interfaces with logical access control systems to verify PIV cards. Upon presentation of a PIV card for system access, the automated verification process authenticates the credential against a trusted certificate authority, ensuring it is valid and issued by an authorized entity as per FIPS Publication 201 standards. This process occurs every time a user attempts to gain access to the system, ensuring continuous enforcement of authentication policies.In parallel, the physical access control systems are equipped with readers that support the validation of Department of Defense Common Access Cards (CAC). Personnel seeking entry must present their CAC to these readers. The validation process is manual but systematic; security personnel are trained to inspect the card's authenticity, check against an access list, and ensure the individual presenting the card matches the photograph and identity on the card. This procedure is enforced at all physical entry points to prevent unauthorized physical access.Both systems are regularly audited for compliance with established policies and procedures. Access logs from both logical and physical systems are reviewed to detect any anomalies or unauthorized attempts to access the system. Additionally, updates to the PIV and CAC validation processes are applied in accordance with changes in federal guidelines and technological advancements.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, the following steps are taken:1. Security categorization is performed to determine the security category of information processed, stored, and transmitted by the cloud system. This ensures that authenticators are protected in line with the highest security category present within the system.2. Access control policies are established within ACME's identity management system, which serve as a foundational security component for managing identities and access permissions. These policies are tailored to reflect the determined security categories, ensuring that authenticators are appropriately safeguarded.3. ACME's secure storage solution is utilized for key management activities, storing cryptographic keys and secrets necessary for authentication processes. This secure storage aligns with the security categorization findings, providing an additional layer of protection for authenticators.4. DevOps management activities integrate security into the continuous deployment pipeline through a defined process implemented by ACME. This includes automated configuration of access controls and regular updates to ACME's identity management and secure storage solutions based on evolving threat intelligence and changes in security categorization.5. Continuous monitoring tools are deployed to detect any deviations from the established access control policies in ACME's identity management system and unauthorized access attempts to ACME's secure storage solution. Alerts are generated for immediate response to potential threats.6. Regular assessments are conducted using automated tools to compare actual state configurations against desired state specifications for authenticators. This ensures ongoing compliance with the protective measures required by the highest security category of information on the systems.

by-components.description: During application development, security measures are integrated to prevent the embedding or storage of unencrypted static authenticators. Developers utilize tools such as Veracode for static code analysis to detect any occurrences of hard-coded credentials within the application's source code. This process is part of a defined process implemented by ACME, ensuring that any code commits are automatically scanned for security vulnerabilities, including the presence of unencrypted static authenticators.Access script management involves reviewing and updating scripts that facilitate access to applications or systems. Scripts are checked to ensure no unencrypted static authenticators are present. This review process is conducted regularly as part of routine maintenance activities. Any identified instances of unencrypted authenticators are immediately remediated by encrypting the credentials or implementing more secure authentication mechanisms.For function key management, a procedure is established where function keys, which may serve as a form of static authenticator, are stored securely. They are encrypted using industry-standard cryptographic methods before being stored or transmitted. The management of these keys includes regular rotation and revocation procedures in case of potential compromise.In addition to proactive measures during development and management processes, Azure Web Application Firewall (WAF) serves as a security component that monitors incoming and outgoing traffic to applications. It helps to block attempts to exploit any potential vulnerabilities related to authentication mechanisms, including the misuse of static authenticators.All these activities form part of an overarching security policy that mandates encryption for all forms of static authenticators within the system's infrastructure. The policy outlines the responsibilities of relevant personnel and dictates the frequency and methodology for conducting security assessments to ensure compliance with this requirement.
ACME System

by-components.description: The system implements an authentication feedback obscuring mechanism to mitigate the risk of unauthorized individuals compromising authentication mechanisms through observation, commonly known as "shoulder surfing." For systems with larger displays such as desktops or notebooks, the threat is more significant. In contrast, mobile devices with smaller screens present a lower risk but have a higher chance of typographic errors due to small keyboards.Upon initiation of the authentication process by users, the system ensures that all password inputs are replaced with asterisks or similar non-revealing placeholders. This applies to all user interfaces across the system, including web applications, desktop clients, and mobile apps. The system is configured to provide immediate feedback obscuration, which means that each character entered by the user is masked promptly after input.In addition to masking input characters, the system is designed to limit the display duration of any authentication feedback. If feedback is provided for user convenience, it appears only briefly before being obscured. This timing is configured to balance usability with security considerations and is based on the sensitivity of the system and potential threat exposure.The implementation includes periodic reviews and updates of the obscuring mechanisms to adapt to evolving threats and changes in system usage patterns. Security personnel ensure that these measures are maintained in accordance with established policies and procedures.DevOps management activities include continuous monitoring and automated testing to verify that the obscuring features function correctly across all components. Any deviations from expected behavior trigger alerts and are addressed promptly according to incident response protocols.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, the following steps are implemented using security components and DevOps management activities:1. Azure Key Vault is configured to enforce multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all operator access. This ensures that any individual attempting to access the cryptographic module must provide multiple forms of verification, thereby reducing the risk of unauthorized access due to compromised credentials.2. Access policies within Azure Key Vault are strictly defined and managed, specifying which users or service principals can perform operations within the Key Vault. These policies are regularly reviewed and updated in accordance with least privilege principles to minimize the potential impact of operator misuse or unauthorized access.3. a defined process implemented by ACME is integrated into the continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipeline to scan for vulnerabilities in code before deployment. It also checks compliance with authentication requirements for cryptographic modules, ensuring that only verified code is deployed.4. Microsoft Defender for Endpoints is utilized to monitor endpoints for suspicious activities related to cryptographic modules. It provides behavioral analytics and threat intelligence to detect and respond to threats targeting operator authentication mechanisms.5. Regular training is provided to operators on the importance of secure authentication practices, including the use of MFA and adherence to policy when accessing cryptographic modules. This human-centric approach reduces the risk posed by social engineering and other tactics that target operator behavior.6. Incident response procedures are established to address any potential breaches or unauthorized access attempts to cryptographic modules. These procedures include immediate revocation of access, analysis of breach methods, and reinforcement of security measures where necessary.7. Audit logs are maintained for all access and actions taken within cryptographic modules. These logs are regularly reviewed by authorized personnel to ensure compliance with authentication policies and to detect any irregularities that may indicate a security concern.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure components and application components, Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is utilized to ensure that non-organizational users are uniquely identified. Each user is assigned a unique identifier within Azure AD which serves as their principal identity for accessing cloud resources. This identification process is critical for establishing an audit trail and for enabling accountability.Authentication of non-organizational users is achieved through the implementation of multi-factor authentication (MFA) in Azure AD, which requires users to provide two or more verification factors to gain access. MFA significantly reduces the risk of unauthorized access resulting from compromised credentials by adding an additional layer of security beyond just username and password.Azure Sentinel, a cloud-native security information and event manager (SIEM) platform, is employed to monitor and review login attempts. By analyzing the logs generated by Azure AD during the authentication process, Azure Sentinel can detect anomalies and potential security threats. In case of any suspicious activities, alerts are generated, and incident response procedures are initiated.Access control policies within Azure AD are configured to enforce appropriate permissions for non-organizational users, ensuring they only have access to resources necessary for their role. These policies are regularly reviewed and updated in accordance with changes in user roles or threat landscapes.DevOps management activities include continuous monitoring of the security posture of the cloud environment. Security scans and compliance checks are performed regularly to ensure that the implemented security measures align with the desired state specifications. Any identified deviations are addressed promptly through a defined process implemented by ACME.

Azure Sentinel supplements this by providing security information and event management (SIEM) capabilities, ensuring that any identity-related events are monitored and appropriately managed. Microsoft InTune, a cloud-based service in the enterprise mobility management (EMM) space, enforces organizational policies and compliance on devices accessing the network.To ensure these profiles conform to open standards, the actual state of identity management profiles is retrieved from Azure Active Directory and compared against the desired state specifications of open standards. This comparison is conducted through automated processes that validate attributes, protocols, and procedures against recognized standards such as SAML, OpenID Connect, and OAuth 2.0.In parallel, Azure Key Vault is utilized to manage cryptographic keys and other secrets used in identity management processes securely. Microsoft Defender for Endpoints provides endpoint security capabilities to detect and respond to threats against identities. Azure DNS is involved in ensuring the integrity and availability of domain name resolution processes critical to identity services.Validation of conformance with open identity management standards involves manual assessment activities where the implemented solutions in Azure Key Vault, Microsoft Defender for Endpoints, and Azure DNS are reviewed against applicable laws, regulations, and guidelines. This includes checking for alignment with Federal Identity, Credential, and Access Management (FICAM) guidelines, NIST standards, and any specific regulatory requirements pertinent to ACME.These activities are documented within policies and procedures that outline roles and responsibilities for managing identity profiles and validating standards conformance. These documents also detail how deviations from expected configurations or standards are handled, including remediation steps and reporting mechanisms to ensure continuous compliance with open identity management standards.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a robust identity validation and verification process is implemented. This process is consistent with the risks associated with the systems, roles, and privileges tied to user accounts.Firstly, Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) serves as the primary component for user authentication. When a user attempts to access the system, Azure AD requires presentation of identity evidence. The system is configured to validate this evidence by checking its genuineness and authenticity. It also confirms that the data within the evidence is correct, current, and pertains to the individual presenting it. This is achieved through automated checks against trusted sources and databases that are part of Azure AD's integrated identity verification framework.The actual state test involves inspecting user authentication logs within Azure AD. These logs contain detailed records of each validation attempt and its outcome. Automated tools are deployed to analyze these logs regularly, identifying successful validations and flagging any anomalies or failures that may indicate a security threat.Secondly, Microsoft InTune complements Azure AD by managing devices used to access the cloud system. It ensures that devices are compliant with security policies before granting access. As part of the verification process, InTune reviews the devices against predefined compliance standards and verifies user identities linked to these devices.The actual state test for device management involves manual review of InTune device management logs. These logs record every instance of device compliance checks and user identity verifications conducted by InTune. Security personnel are tasked with examining these logs to ensure that only verified users on compliant devices can access the system.Both components—Azure AD for user authentication and Microsoft InTune for device management—work in tandem to establish a secure environment. By validating and verifying identity evidence through these mechanisms, the cloud system effectively mitigates potential threats posed by unauthorized access or compromised credentials. This systematic approach aligns with a defined process implemented by ACME for ensuring that accounts and authenticators are correctly established and bound to legitimate users, thereby enhancing overall security posture.
ACME System

by-components.description: The system employs an out-of-band verification process for user address confirmation as part of its identity proofing procedure. During the registration phase, the user provides an address which is then cross-verified against existing records to ensure it is not self-asserted but rather derived from authoritative sources. This address could be either a physical location or a digital endpoint, such as an email or phone number.Upon successful verification of the user's address from records, the system generates a temporary enrollment code or sends a notice of proofing to the confirmed address. This step is crucial as it ensures that only the legitimate user who has access to the verified address can proceed with the enrollment process.The delivery of the temporary code or proofing notice is conducted through a channel separate from where the initial registration request was received. For instance, if the registration was done online, the confirmation might be sent via postal mail to a physical address or through an SMS to a mobile number.To validate that the out-of-band verification has been completed successfully, there are manual checks in place. These involve verifying API calls and other relevant activities within a defined process implemented by ACME to confirm that each step was performed according to established procedures and that no unauthorized changes were made during the process.This verification process is documented and auditable, providing clear evidence for review by an auditor. The documentation includes details on how the out-of-band verification was conducted, including any APIs used, the method of sending out enrollment codes or notices, and how responses were tracked and validated.

by-components.description: The system's incident response capability is tested annually to ensure readiness and effectiveness. The frequency of these tests is predetermined and adhered to as part of the incident response plan. During these tests, a variety of scenarios and attack vectors are employed to challenge the system and identify potential weaknesses.Tabletop exercises are conducted to simulate incidents that may affect the system's infrastructure components and application components. Participants from various teams, including security operations, DevOps, and management, gather to walk through these scenarios step by step. This exercise evaluates the team's understanding of their roles and the incident response plan, as well as the communication flow during an incident.Simulated phishing attacks are executed to test the system's resilience against social engineering tactics. These simulations assess both technical controls, such as email filtering systems, and human factors, like employee awareness and reaction to suspicious emails. The results from these simulations inform improvements in training programs and adjustments to security measures.Throughout these activities, both qualitative and quantitative data are collected. Qualitative assessments provide insights into the team's decision-making processes and coordination efforts. Quantitative data, such as response times and success rates in identifying and mitigating threats, offer measurable evidence of the system's incident response capabilities.Findings from these tests lead to updates in policies, procedures, or system configurations to bolster security postures. Lessons learned are documented and incorporated into future planning to continuously improve incident response processes. All activities are aligned with FedRAMP guidance on writing System Security Plans, ensuring compliance with federal requirements for cloud service providers.
ACME implements this control using a defined process implemented by ACME. Team Member 1 and Team Member 2 are responsible for ensuring compliance with this control.

Upon detecting a threat, these tools trigger the Incident Reporting System to initiate the automated response protocol.Furthermore, security policies and procedures are regularly reviewed and updated to align with evolving threats and compliance requirements. This includes refining the criteria that determine which incidents should be escalated and how they should be communicated to relevant parties.All personnel involved in incident handling are trained on these procedures, ensuring that they understand their roles within the incident response process. Regular drills and simulations are conducted to test the effectiveness of both the automated systems and the human elements of the response strategy.

by-components.description: The system's infrastructure components and application components are safeguarded from threats through a comprehensive approach that integrates security components and DevOps management activities. The process begins with the identification of all relevant entities involved in the supply chain, including product developers, system integrators, manufacturers, packagers, assemblers, distributors, vendors, and resellers.For each identified entity, there is a clear delineation of roles and responsibilities concerning incident response. This is documented within the Incident Response Plan, which is regularly reviewed and updated to reflect any changes in the supply chain or organizational structure.ACME's central security information and event management (SIEM) platform is configured to automatically detect incidents by analyzing logs and activities across the cloud environment. Upon detection of an incident, the SIEM platform triggers predefined workflows that include notifying designated personnel within the organization and relevant external parties in the supply chain.The notification process adheres to established communication protocols that specify what information should be shared. This ensures that only pertinent details about the incident, such as nature, scope, impact, and potential root cause, are disseminated to prevent unnecessary exposure of sensitive information.DevOps management activities play a crucial role in maintaining a secure development lifecycle. These activities include continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines with built-in security checks, automated vulnerability scanning of code repositories and container images, and regular penetration testing to uncover potential weaknesses before they can be exploited.Additionally, personnel involved in supply chain governance receive training on recognizing and responding to supply chain incidents. They are also made aware of the Federal Acquisition Security Council (FASC) guidelines to ensure compliance with federal standards.In case of a supply chain incident, the established procedures dictate a swift analysis to determine its extent and impact. The findings from this analysis guide remediation efforts and help identify improvements to prevent similar incidents in the future.All these measures are documented within standard operating procedures (SOPs), which are accessible to relevant staff members. These SOPs ensure consistent application of security practices across the organization and facilitate quick reference during an incident response scenario.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, the security and DevOps management activities are orchestrated as follows:1. A web application service is established to serve as the primary interface for incident response information dissemination. This website is hosted on a secure cloud platform with appropriate security controls in place, such as firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and secure coding practices to ensure its availability and integrity.2. Incident response information is made available on this website, which is continuously updated with the latest guidance, best practices, and contact information for incident response teams. This ensures that users can access relevant information in a timely manner.3. The website is configured to provide API endpoints that allow users to programmatically retrieve incident response information. This enables integration with other systems or applications within the organization's environment, facilitating automated dissemination of information.4. A defined process implemented by ACME is leveraged to proactively monitor security events and provide incident response information. The process is configured to analyze logs and activities across the cloud environment to detect potential security incidents.5. Customized alerts and workflows are created within the defined process based on predefined criteria indicative of a security incident. These alerts are configured to automatically notify users via email or other communication channels when an incident is detected.6. A defined process implemented by ACME is utilized to query and analyze log data for deeper insights into security incidents. This capability aids in understanding the nature of security threats and improving incident response strategies.7. The DevOps team implements continuous monitoring and regular audits of both the web application service and the defined process configurations to ensure they remain effective in providing incident response assistance.8. Security policies and procedures are documented and communicated to all relevant personnel, ensuring that they understand their roles in the incident response process and how to utilize the provided tools effectively.9. Training sessions are conducted for users on how to access and use the incident response resources available through the web application service and the defined process alerts.10. Regular exercises simulating various types of security incidents are carried out to evaluate the effectiveness of the incident response capabilities and make necessary adjustments to procedures or configurations.

Initially, ACME defines requirements for responding to information spillage incidents within the incident response plans. These plans delineate clear roles and responsibilities for personnel and outline specific actions required during a spillage event.Next, regular incident response training is implemented to ensure that all personnel are aware of their responsibilities in the event of an information spillage. The training content is regularly updated to reflect evolving threats and organizational changes.DevOps management activities integrate security into the software development lifecycle. Security checks and controls are embedded into continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines. Automated tools scan for vulnerabilities and misconfigurations, ensuring that any potential spillage vectors are identified and remediated promptly.Additionally, logging and monitoring systems are deployed across the cloud infrastructure to detect unusual activities that may indicate a spillage incident. These systems generate alerts that trigger predefined incident response workflows, ensuring a swift and coordinated reaction to potential spillages.Security components such as Data Loss Prevention (DLP) tools are configured to prevent unauthorized data transfers and alert on policy violations. Encryption technologies are employed both for data at rest and in transit, reducing the risk of exposure even if unauthorized access occurs.Regular audits and assessments validate the effectiveness of these measures. Incident response drills are conducted, involving all relevant stakeholders, to test ACME's preparedness and ability to respond effectively to real-world spillage events.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a comprehensive approach integrating security components and a defined process implemented by ACME is employed.Initially, procedures are established to ensure that personnel can maintain productivity during incidents of system contamination. This involves identifying alternate systems or temporary workspaces that users can access when primary systems are compromised. Access control measures are then configured to grant permissions to these alternative resources without compromising security.Simultaneously, secure configuration management practices are applied to maintain the integrity of both primary and alternate systems. These practices include regular updates, patches, and configuration checks to prevent vulnerabilities that could lead to information spills.User behavior analytics tools are deployed to monitor for anomalous activity that may indicate a spill or contamination. In the event of an incident, these tools help in quickly pinpointing the affected components, enabling targeted and efficient corrective actions.Forensics capabilities are integrated to investigate and analyze the cause and impact of any contamination. This ensures that lessons are learned and appropriate measures are taken to prevent recurrence.Data security mechanisms, including encryption and access controls, protect critical data even in the event of a spill. These mechanisms ensure that data remains accessible to authorized personnel through alternative devices or locations as necessary.Threat protection systems, such as intrusion detection and prevention solutions, actively defend against ongoing threats. They provide real-time alerts and automatic responses to potential spills, reducing the window of exposure and impact on operations.In the case of an information spill, a defined process implemented by ACME facilitates swift recovery by leveraging automation for rapid deployment of clean environments. This minimizes downtime and restores access to essential applications and data for personnel.Throughout this process, automated testing tools validate access controls and data availability on alternate devices or locations, ensuring that critical business functions continue uninterrupted while contaminated systems undergo corrective actions.

Upon an employee's termination, the offboarding process is initiated, where all authenticators and credentials associated with the individual are immediately revoked. The Access Control team ensures that any hardware authentication tokens, keys, identification cards, and building passes are retrieved. Simultaneously, the Identity Management system is updated to reflect the change in employment status, triggering the deactivation of the individual's system accounts. This process is completed within a predefined time period as specified in ACME's access control policy to minimize the risk of unauthorized access.
ACME System

Upon termination of employment, Human Resources (HR) coordinates with Security and IT departments to ensure that exit interviews are conducted. These interviews serve to reaffirm the security constraints imposed on former employees and to secure proper accountability for system-related property. HR ensures that all hardware authentication tokens, technical manuals, keys, identification cards, and building passes are returned by the departing employee.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, the following steps are implemented via a defined process implemented by ACME:1. A vulnerability scanning tool is selected and integrated into the DevOps management activities. This tool is responsible for identifying potential vulnerabilities within the system's infrastructure and applications.2. The vulnerability scanning tool is configured to automatically update its vulnerability database. This ensures that the tool is equipped with the most current information regarding new vulnerabilities as they are discovered.3. Scheduled scans are established within the DevOps workflow, ensuring regular and systematic scanning of all cloud system components. These scans are programmed to run at intervals that align with the organization's risk management strategy, typically on a daily or weekly basis.4. Upon completion of each scan, the results are reviewed by designated security personnel. This team is tasked with analyzing the findings, prioritizing identified vulnerabilities based on their severity, and formulating appropriate response actions.5. Identified vulnerabilities are addressed through a well-defined remediation process. This may involve patching software, reconfiguring security settings, or other corrective actions deemed necessary to mitigate risks.6. The effectiveness of remediation efforts is verified by conducting follow-up scans. These subsequent scans ensure that vulnerabilities have been successfully addressed and that no new issues have arisen as a result of the changes made.7. All vulnerability scanning activities and outcomes are documented in accordance with organizational policies. This documentation serves as a record of compliance with security requirements and aids in continuous monitoring efforts.8. The organization maintains an incident response plan that includes procedures for addressing vulnerabilities that may be exploited before remediation can occur. This plan is regularly tested and updated to remain effective against evolving threats.9. Security personnel receive ongoing training to stay abreast of emerging vulnerabilities and effective mitigation techniques. This ensures that those responsible for managing system security are equipped with up-to-date knowledge and skills.10. The organization enforces strict access controls to limit exposure to potential vulnerabilities. Only authorized personnel have access to perform scans and implement remediation measures, reducing the risk of unauthorized changes or insider threats.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a comprehensive vulnerability scanning strategy is implemented. This strategy encompasses both breadth and depth of coverage within the system, ensuring that potential vulnerabilities are identified and addressed.Firstly, the vulnerability scanning tool is configured to scan all system components. This includes infrastructure components such as servers, network devices, and storage systems, as well as application components like web services and databases. The configuration ensures that the scanning tool covers a defined percentage of these components, aligning with ACME's risk tolerance. The scanning tool automatically executes scans on a scheduled basis, providing real-time data on coverage percentage.Secondly, the scanning tool is tailored to target specific types of systems based on their criticality and function within the cloud environment. For example, it may prioritize systems that store sensitive information or support critical business operations. This targeted approach allows for more efficient use of resources while maintaining a focus on high-risk areas.Thirdly, the depth of scanning is addressed by configuring the tool to monitor various levels of system design. It assesses components at different layers, from underlying hardware to application code, ensuring comprehensive visibility into potential vulnerabilities at every level of the system architecture.In addition to tool configuration, DevOps management activities play a crucial role in maintaining security. These activities include regular updates to the vulnerability database to ensure new threats are detected, patch management processes to remediate identified vulnerabilities promptly, and a defined process implemented by ACME that integrates security checks into the software development lifecycle.Regular reviews of scanning tool configurations are conducted to verify that both breadth and depth coverage remain effective and aligned with current threat landscapes. Adjustments are made as necessary based on emerging threats, changes in system architecture, or shifts in organizational risk tolerance.Documentation is maintained for all scanning activities, including configuration settings, scan schedules, and remediation actions taken in response to identified vulnerabilities. This documentation serves as evidence of compliance with FedRAMP requirements and supports ongoing risk management efforts.

by-components.description: Privileged access authorization is granted to Azure Sentinel and Microsoft Defender for Endpoints, enabling comprehensive vulnerability scanning of selected system components. This process begins with the provisioning of privileged accounts that are strictly controlled and monitored. Access to these accounts is limited to authorized personnel who have undergone rigorous vetting and have a legitimate need for such access in the performance of their duties.The scanning activity is conducted using Azure Sentinel, which integrates with Microsoft Defender for Endpoints to perform scans that are more intrusive than regular scans, due to the level of access provided. The privileged access allows the scanning tools to thoroughly assess the system for vulnerabilities that could be missed with standard user permissions.During the scanning process, Azure Key Vault plays a critical role in managing cryptographic keys and secrets that protect sensitive data. Access control policies within Azure Key Vault ensure that only authorized scanning processes can retrieve or interact with the keys necessary for decrypting sensitive information. This ensures that even during vulnerability scanning, sensitive data remains protected from unauthorized access.The actual state test involves executing vulnerability scanning under privileged access conditions and verifying that the scans occur as expected without unauthorized disclosure of sensitive information. The results of these scans are then reviewed to ensure they meet the desired state specification of thoroughness and sensitivity protection.This process is automated to minimize human error and provide a consistent scanning routine. Automation also facilitates rapid response to detected vulnerabilities, allowing for immediate remediation actions where necessary.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a public reporting channel is established. This channel is easily accessible and discoverable by external researchers and users, ensuring transparency in the process of vulnerability reporting.The reporting channel is clearly marked with instructions and guidelines that encourage good-faith security research. It outlines the steps for responsible disclosure, including how to submit a report and what information should be included to help ACME validate and address the reported vulnerability.Upon receipt of a vulnerability report, the incident response team is notified. This team is trained in forensics and incident handling and follows a defined process implemented by ACME to validate the reported vulnerability. The process includes initial assessment, reproduction of the issue, impact analysis, and development of remediation measures.A communication plan is activated to maintain contact with the reporter, acknowledging the receipt of the report and providing updates on the remediation progress. This plan respects the confidentiality of the reporter while ensuring timely updates are communicated.ACME sets a reasonable time frame for addressing reported vulnerabilities before public disclosure. This time frame is communicated to the reporter and adheres to industry best practices, balancing the need for public awareness with the necessity of preventing exploitation.Throughout this process, a defined process implemented by ACME integrates security considerations into software development lifecycle stages. Security patches and updates are developed, tested, and deployed promptly to mitigate any confirmed vulnerabilities.Documentation of all reported vulnerabilities, along with their resolution status, is maintained as part of an ongoing risk assessment effort. This documentation feeds into continuous monitoring strategies to enhance overall system security posture.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a comprehensive approach integrating security components and DevOps management activities is employed.Firstly, Veracode, Zscaler, and Azure Web Application Firewall (WAF) are utilized to respond to security assessment findings. Veracode scans applications for vulnerabilities, Zscaler secures internet traffic, and Azure WAF protects web applications from common exploits. Upon identification of a threat, response procedures are initiated where the findings are evaluated against ACME's risk tolerance. If the risk exceeds tolerance levels, immediate remediation actions are taken, which may include applying patches, revising configurations, or enhancing security controls.For privacy-related threats, Vanta and FreshService provide compliance tracking and incident management capabilities. Privacy assessment findings trigger response procedures that align with ACME's privacy risk tolerance. Actions such as updating privacy policies, conducting additional training, or implementing more stringent data protection measures ensure that privacy risks are managed effectively.Monitoring findings from Microsoft Defender for Endpoints and Azure Sentinel are addressed by established response procedures. These tools offer advanced threat detection and response capabilities. Identified risks are assessed, and if mitigation is required based on ACME's risk tolerance, immediate action is taken. This could involve isolating affected systems, conducting forensic analysis, or adjusting security policies.Lastly, audit findings from Azure Log Analytics and Microsoft Endpoint Manager trigger audit response procedures. These tools provide insights into system operations and compliance status. Findings that present a risk beyond acceptable levels prompt immediate action to rectify issues such as non-compliance with policies or unexpected changes in system behavior.In all cases, if immediate mitigation is not possible, a plan of action and milestones is generated to track the resolution process. ACME ensures that all responses to identified risks are documented and reviewed in accordance with its overall risk management strategy. This structured approach ensures that threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components are effectively mitigated in line with ACME's risk tolerance and compliance requirements.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a criticality analysis is conducted to identify and prioritize the protection of key assets. The process begins with system engineers performing a defined process implemented by ACME to determine mission-critical functions and components. This involves mapping out organizational missions supported by the system, breaking them down into specific functions, and tracing these functions back to the hardware, software, and firmware components responsible for their execution.During this analysis, attention is given to system functionality requirements, interfaces, dependencies, laws, regulations, policies, standards, and directives. Components that provide unmediated access to critical functions are flagged as critical due to their potential vulnerabilities.The timing of the criticality analysis is crucial; it is integrated into decision points within the system development life cycle, particularly when architecture or design is being developed, modified, or upgraded. Conducting this analysis early allows for design modifications that can reduce the critical nature of components through strategies such as redundancy or alternative pathways.Moreover, protection measures required by development contractors are influenced by the outcomes of the criticality analysis. This ensures that security considerations are embedded in the development process from the outset.The operational environment's impact on component criticality is also assessed, considering connections to cyber-physical systems, devices, system-of-systems, and outsourced IT services.Finally, beyond system and component analysis, information criticality analysis forms part of security categorization efforts. This holistic approach ensures that all aspects of the cloud system's security posture are addressed systematically and strategically.The defined parameters for this process include specifying which systems, components, or services require analysis for criticality and outlining the decision points in the life cycle when such analyses must be performed. By adhering to these steps and parameters, threats to infrastructure and application components are effectively mitigated through informed security planning and implementation.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a comprehensive approach involving security components and DevOps management activities is employed.Firstly, Azure Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) roles are defined and assigned to ensure that only authorized personnel have access to specific resources within the cloud environment. These roles are carefully crafted to grant minimum necessary permissions aligning with the principle of least privilege. The assignment of these roles is regularly reviewed and updated in response to changes in personnel or their responsibilities.Secondly, Azure Blob Storage bucket permissions are configured to control access at the data storage level. Permissions are set to restrict who can read, write, or delete data within the storage buckets. Access control lists and shared access signatures are utilized to enforce these permissions, ensuring that data is accessible only to authenticated and authorized users.In addition, Azure Sentinel, a cloud-native Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system, is leveraged for continuous monitoring and alerting on potential security incidents. Alert rules are established based on predefined or custom criteria to detect anomalous activities indicative of security threats. When alerts are triggered, they are reviewed by security analysts who investigate and respond accordingly.Furthermore, DevOps management activities include the use of automated deployment pipelines that incorporate security checks and compliance validation as part of a defined process implemented by ACME. This ensures that any changes made to the infrastructure or applications are vetted for security concerns before being deployed into production.All these measures are documented in developer documentation which provides a description of the functional properties of these controls. This documentation serves as a reference for both implementation and ongoing management of the security posture of the cloud environment.Regular assessments are conducted to verify that the actual state of the system aligns with the desired state specifications. These assessments involve manual reviews where necessary documentation is retrieved and examined against the test cases to ensure compliance with FedRAMP requirements.

by-components.description: The mitigation of threats to the cloud system's infrastructure components and application components is systematically addressed through a series of security components and DevOps management activities.Firstly, the high-level design documentation for subsystems that manage Azure Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) roles is developed and maintained. This documentation outlines the architecture of these subsystems, detailing how they interact with other parts of the system to enforce access policies. It includes diagrams and descriptions that explain the flow of information and decision-making processes used to grant or deny access based on assigned roles.Next, low-level design documentation for modules handling Azure Blob Storage Bucket permissions is created. This detailed documentation describes the specific implementation of permission controls at the module level, including data structures, algorithms, and interaction with storage APIs. It also covers error handling strategies and logging mechanisms that provide an audit trail for access attempts and changes to permissions.DevOps management activities include regular updates to both high-level and low-level design documents to reflect changes in the system architecture or operational procedures. These activities ensure that designs remain current and accurately represent the system's security posture.In addition, security features are implemented as per design documents. This includes configuring RBAC roles within Azure to limit access based on least privilege principles, regularly reviewing role assignments, and adjusting them as necessary to accommodate changes in personnel or responsibilities.For Azure Blob Storage Buckets, permissions are set according to the principle of least privilege, ensuring that only authorized entities have access to data stored within them. Regular audits of these permissions are conducted to verify compliance with policy and to detect any deviations that may indicate a security risk.Furthermore, all design and implementation information is supplemented with metadata such as manufacturer details, version numbers, verification hash signatures, software libraries used, procurement dates, and vendor or download sources. This metadata provides traceability and aids in the verification process by ensuring that only authorized and validated components are utilized within the system.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a comprehensive approach is taken that integrates security and privacy engineering principles throughout the system development life cycle (SDLC). The process begins with the system specification phase, where security and privacy requirements are defined and incorporated into the foundational design. This includes establishing security policies, architectural designs that support layered defenses, and the selection of appropriate controls tailored to organizational needs.During the design phase, physical and logical boundaries are delineated to ensure proper segmentation and isolation of resources. Security architecture is validated against these principles to ensure robustness against potential threats. Privacy considerations are also embedded within the design to address any concerns related to personal data handling.In the development phase, developers trained in secure coding practices implement the system components adhering to the predefined security and privacy guidelines. Code repositories are subject to regular inspections to enforce compliance with these principles. Threat modeling activities are conducted to identify potential attack vectors and incorporate compensating controls into a defined process implemented by ACME.As part of implementation, systems undergo rigorous testing to validate that all security and privacy measures are effectively in place. Configuration management processes ensure that deployments maintain consistency with the security model, and any deviations are identified and rectified.Finally, during modification or upgrade phases, change management procedures are strictly followed to ensure that any alterations continue to adhere to security and privacy engineering principles. Patching procedures are implemented in a manner that maintains the integrity of security layers and privacy protections without introducing new vulnerabilities.Throughout each stage of the SDLC, devops management activities play a crucial role in maintaining a continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipeline that upholds security standards. Automation tools are employed for code scanning, vulnerability assessments, and configuration checks to provide real-time feedback on security posture.

If discrepancies are found between the desired and actual states, remediation activities are initiated promptly.All activities related to identifying and managing functions, ports, protocols, and services are documented in accordance with established policies and procedures. by-components.description: Azure Virtual Networks (VNets), Azure Compute Virtual Machines, Azure SQL Servers, and Azure Application Service Environments (ASE) are configured to limit information processing to designated areas. These components are deployed following ACME policies that dictate specific geographic or regional boundaries for processing activities. The deployment configurations of these resources are documented and periodically reviewed against the policy requirements to ensure compliance.For data storage, Azure Storage, Azure SQL Server, Azure BLOB Storage, and Azure Key Vault are utilized. These services are set up to store data within approved locations as determined by ACME policies. Configuration settings for each storage service reflect the approved locations, with access controls and network security groups in place to enforce the geographical restrictions.System services such as Azure Web App Services, Azure CDN, Azure DevOps Pipelines, Microsoft Sentinel, and Microsoft Defender for Endpoints are similarly managed to ensure they operate within ACME's approved locations. Deployment scripts and service configurations include location specifications that align with policy mandates. The management of these services includes regular audits to verify that the actual deployment locations match the specified policy-approved locations.In all cases, the configuration settings for these components and services are accessible for review and verification against ACME policies. Any deviations from the policy-defined locations trigger a defined process implemented by ACME to bring the components back into compliance. Documentation is maintained for all configurations and changes to ensure traceability and accountability in managing location-based restrictions.The system's infrastructure and application components are protected through these security components and DevOps management activities by enforcing location restrictions that align with ACME policies. This approach mitigates threats related to unauthorized data processing or storage locations, which could impact incident response activities and adherence to governing laws and protocols. These measures contribute to maintaining the integrity of the system's operations in support of ACME's mission and business functions.

by-components.description: The mitigation of threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components using security components and DevOps management activities is systematically addressed through static code analysis. This process begins with the integration of static code analysis from a defined process implemented by ACME, into the software development lifecycle, configured to scan the codebase automatically for common flaws and vulnerabilities.During the development phase, each code change triggers an automated scan by the selected static code analysis tool. This ensures that potential weaknesses are identified early, allowing for prompt remediation. The results of these scans are then compiled into a report by the tool itself.Following the generation of this report, it is reviewed by developers and security professionals who inspect the identified defects. This collaborative review process is crucial for distinguishing between true vulnerabilities and false positives. It also ensures that defects receive proper attention for remediation.Once defects are confirmed, developers are tasked with addressing them. The remediation actions taken are documented to provide a clear trail of evidence for each vulnerability from detection to resolution. This documentation serves as proof of adherence to secure coding practices and is stored securely within ACME’s documentation repository.To ensure continuous improvement, defect density metrics for critical defect types are aggregated and monitored over time. A high density of ignored findings would trigger an evaluation of the analysis process or tool to identify any issues that may be leading to an excessive number of false positives.This structured approach to static code analysis within DevOps practices not only mitigates threats but also fosters a culture of security awareness among developers. By embedding these activities into routine development processes, ACME maintains a robust defense against vulnerabilities in its cloud system infrastructure and application components.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a defined process implemented by ACME is applied that leverages Azure Web App Service and Azure SQL Server for hosting user functionality separately from system management functionality. This separation is achieved by utilizing different computing resources or network addresses to host user interface services, ensuring no overlap with system management interfaces. By doing so, the potential attack surface is reduced, as malicious actors cannot exploit user interfaces to gain unauthorized access to system management areas.Furthermore, Azure Active Directory and Azure Key Vault are employed to provide robust authentication mechanisms, particularly for administrative interfaces. Separate authentication methods are implemented for these interfaces compared to what is used for standard user access. This separation ensures that even if user credentials are compromised, administrative functions remain protected due to the distinct authentication processes.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a set of security components and DevOps management activities are employed.Firstly, Azure Network Security Groups (NSGs) are configured to establish a barrier against unauthorized information transfer through shared system resources. NSGs serve as a firewall for virtual network resources, where rules are defined to allow or deny network traffic to resources. The configuration of NSGs involves specifying inbound and outbound security rules that match ACME's security policies. These rules are designed to permit traffic from known, authorized sources and destinations while blocking potentially malicious traffic. The NSG rules are continuously reviewed and updated in response to emerging threats or changes in the operational environment.Secondly, the Azure Key Vault is utilized to manage sensitive information such as secrets, keys, and certificates. Access to this sensitive information is strictly controlled through access policies that define who can retrieve, list, or manage the data within the Key Vault. These policies are crafted following the principle of least privilege, ensuring that only authorized personnel with a legitimate need can access the sensitive data. The access control mechanisms include multifactor authentication and role-based access controls that align with job functions and responsibilities.DevOps management activities play a crucial role in maintaining the security posture of these components. This includes routine monitoring for compliance with established security configurations, automated deployment of updates or patches to address vulnerabilities, and regular audits to verify that access policies reflect current operational requirements.Furthermore, all activities related to configuration changes, access control adjustments, and rule modifications are logged and monitored. Anomaly detection systems analyze these logs for unusual patterns that may indicate a breach or misuse of shared resources.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, the following steps are implemented using security components and DevOps management activities:1. Azure Network Security Groups (NSGs) are configured to establish boundaries around the cloud resources, effectively limiting the number of external network connections to the system. NSGs contain a list of security rules that allow or deny network traffic to resources connected to Azure Virtual Networks (VNets). These rules are meticulously crafted in accordance with organizational policies and industry best practices to ensure only authorized traffic can access the system.2. Network Configuration Management procedures are in place to regularly review and update NSG configurations. This includes adding, modifying, or removing rules to adapt to changing security requirements or threat landscapes. The changes are documented, reviewed, and approved by authorized personnel before implementation.3. Azure VNets are utilized to segment the network, creating isolated sections within the cloud environment. This segmentation is strategically designed to control external network connections and prevent unauthorized access between different segments of the network.4. Within each VNet, subnets are defined to further refine network segmentation and apply more granular control over traffic flow. Subnet-level NSG associations are made to enforce security policies at a more specific level within the VNet.5. Continuous monitoring tools are employed to automatically detect any deviations from the desired state of network connections. These tools alert security teams if the number of external connections exceeds predefined thresholds, prompting immediate investigation and remediation actions.6. All configuration changes and network traffic are logged for auditing purposes. These logs are regularly reviewed by security analysts to ensure compliance with security policies and identify any suspicious activities that may indicate a breach or attempted breach.7. Security incident response procedures are established so that in the event of a detected anomaly or breach, there is a clear protocol for containment, eradication, recovery, and post-incident analysis.By implementing these steps, the system ensures that external network connections are limited, monitored, and managed in alignment with federal guidelines such as the Trusted Internet Connection initiative, thereby reducing the attack surface and enhancing the overall security posture during both stable operations and transition periods between technologies.

by-components.description: The Azure Network Security Groups (NSGs) are configured to implement a default deny-all rule for both inbound and outbound network communications traffic. This configuration establishes a baseline security posture that prohibits all connections unless explicitly permitted. The NSG rules are regularly reviewed to confirm that they continue to enforce the deny-all policy effectively, ensuring that no unauthorized traffic can traverse the network.To facilitate essential and approved system connections, specific rules are added to the NSGs that define exceptions to the default deny stance. These rules are crafted based on a thorough analysis of the system's operational requirements and are limited to only those connections deemed necessary for business functionality. Each exception is documented, including a justification for its necessity, and is subject to approval by authorized personnel before implementation.For the Azure Application Service, an automated monitoring solution is in place to oversee API calls. This solution is programmed to detect and log API call activity, allowing for real-time analysis and response. The monitoring focuses on identifying any deviations from the established pattern of approved and essential system connections. Any such deviations trigger alerts, which are then investigated promptly.The combination of NSG rule enforcement and proactive API call monitoring ensures that the cloud system's infrastructure and application components are protected against unauthorized access and potential threats. DevOps management activities include regular audits of security group configurations, updates to access control lists in line with changing requirements, and continuous improvement of monitoring capabilities to adapt to evolving threat landscapes.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats associated with split tunneling in the cloud system's infrastructure, a comprehensive approach is adopted that involves configuring remote devices, provisioning secure VPN connections, and enforcing policies through a defined process implemented by ACME.Firstly, remote device configurations are established to disable split tunneling capabilities. This is achieved by locking down network settings on each device to prevent users from altering the configurations that would enable split tunneling. The configurations are managed centrally to ensure consistency across all remote devices.Secondly, a Virtual Private Network (VPN) is provisioned for all remote connections. The VPN setup includes strong authentication mechanisms and encryption protocols to secure the data transmission between the remote device and the organizational systems. The VPN is configured to allow connectivity only to managed and named environments or a specific set of pre-approved IP addresses. Users are not granted control over the VPN settings, which prevents them from creating unauthorized external connections.A defined process implemented by ACME plays a crucial role in maintaining the security posture. These activities include continuous monitoring of remote device configurations and VPN connections to detect any deviations from the desired state. Automated tools are employed to perform regular checks and audits of the configurations and connections. Users are trained on the risks of split tunneling and are made aware of the organization's policies regarding remote access.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a series of security components and DevOps management activities are employed. The process begins with the deployment of Azure Network Security Groups, which serve as boundary protection devices at managed interfaces, including routers, firewalls, and application gateways.Firstly, a fail-secure mechanism is implemented within these devices. This mechanism ensures that in the event of an operational failure, the security posture is maintained by defaulting to a state that prevents unauthorized access or data leakage. The configuration of these devices is set to deny all traffic unless explicitly allowed by security policies, ensuring that only legitimate traffic can traverse the network.Secondly, regular network security assessments are conducted to validate the effectiveness of these mechanisms. These assessments include testing the response of boundary protection devices under failure conditions to ensure they indeed fail secure. Any identified vulnerabilities or deviations from the expected secure state trigger immediate remediation actions.Additionally, continuous monitoring tools are integrated into the infrastructure to detect any operational failures in real-time. Alerts are generated for any anomalies or malfunctions that could potentially lead to a compromise in the fail-secure posture.DevOps management activities play a crucial role in maintaining the desired state of security. Automated deployment pipelines are configured to enforce security best practices during both development and operations. This includes automated scripts that verify security configurations as part of a defined process implemented by ACME.In case of device failures, an incident response plan is activated, outlining procedures for rapid recovery and analysis. This plan includes steps for preserving evidence for forensic analysis and restoring operations with minimal downtime while maintaining security controls.Lastly, documentation is maintained detailing all configurations, policies, and procedures related to boundary protection devices. This ensures that any changes are tracked and can be audited against established security baselines.

props.remarks: The Implementation Status for the control SC-8 is IMPLEMENTED

values: confidentiality AND integrity

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a comprehensive approach encompassing both security components and DevOps management activities is employed.Firstly, all information transmitted across internal and external networks is encrypted using industry-standard encryption techniques. Network components such as servers, routers, and switches are configured to enforce secure transmission protocols, ensuring that data in transit is protected against interception and modification.For classified information, protected distribution systems are utilized. Communication equipment is set up with adequate electromagnetic, acoustical, electrical, and physical controls to allow for the unencrypted transmission of classified data within a secure environment. This ensures that even sensitive information remains confidential and its integrity is maintained during transmission.DevOps management activities play a crucial role in maintaining the security posture of the cloud system. Continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines include security checks to ensure that any changes to the network configuration or application code do not compromise transmission security. Automated tools scan for vulnerabilities and misconfigurations that could affect data confidentiality or integrity.In cases where commercial transmission services are used, ACME evaluates the confidentiality and integrity services offered as part of standard telecommunications packages. If these services do not meet the required security standards, compensating controls are implemented. This may include additional layers of encryption, the use of virtual private networks (VPNs), or other security measures that provide equivalent protection.Regular assessments are conducted to verify the effectiveness of these controls. Automated tools check that protected distribution systems are functioning correctly and that encryption is applied consistently across all transmitted data. Manual reviews are also performed to validate that the policies and procedures related to transmission security are being followed by personnel.Azure FIPS validated cryptography modules are utilized for all data in transit, including the following data flows:Crossing the system boundary (CDN, Gateways)Between compute instances - including containers (Azure VNets, AppService Environments)From a compute instance to storage (Azure VNets)Replication between availability zones (Azure SQL and BLOB infrastructure)Transmission of backups to storage (Azure SQL and BLOB infrastructure)From a load balancer to a compute instance (Azure VNets and AppServices Environments)Flows from management tools required for their work – e.g., log collection, scanning, etc. (Azure infrastructure, Veracode ATO)
