by-components.description: The Azure Web App Service is configured to enforce TLS encryption for all incoming and outgoing communications, ensuring that data in transit is protected against eavesdropping and tampering. The service requires HTTPS for all web traffic, with the appropriate certificates managed and regularly updated to prevent exploitation of outdated encryption standards.For the Azure SQL Server, connections are established using TLS, with enforced encryption at the database level. This setup ensures that any data moving between the server and clients remains confidential and unaltered. The server is configured to deny any connection requests that do not support TLS encryption.Within Azure CDN, TLS is utilized to secure content delivery. By leveraging the content delivery network's built-in capabilities, data transmitted from origin servers to end-users is encrypted, mitigating risks associated with interception or alteration during transit.Azure Virtual Networks (VNets) implement IPSec for securing network traffic across the virtual network infrastructure. This includes encrypting packet payloads and authenticating packet headers to maintain the integrity and confidentiality of data as it traverses the network.DevOps management activities include automated deployment scripts that enforce security configurations as code, ensuring that TLS and IPSec settings are consistently applied across all environments. Regular scans are conducted to validate the implementation of cryptographic mechanisms, and any deviations are automatically reported for remediation.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats associated with inactive or expired network sessions within the cloud system's infrastructure, ACME Virtual Networks and Network Security Groups are employed to enforce network disconnect policies. The process begins with the configuration of ACME Virtual Networks to automatically terminate network connections at the end of each session. This is achieved by de-allocating TCP/IP address or port pairs at the operating system level, ensuring that once a user ends their session, no residual network connectivity remains that could be exploited by unauthorized entities.Additionally, ACME Network Security Groups are configured with parameters that define specific time periods of inactivity. After this defined period, which is established based on organizational requirements and the sensitivity of the data being accessed, any network connection showing no activity is automatically terminated. This measure prevents potential attackers from exploiting idle connections to gain unauthorized access or perform malicious activities.The implementation includes setting up automated monitoring and logging mechanisms to track active connections and their duration. Upon detection of a session exceeding the predefined inactivity threshold, ACME Network Security Groups trigger an automatic disconnection process. This process involves de-allocating networking assignments at both the operating system and application levels to ensure a complete termination of the communication session.To validate the effectiveness of these measures, simulated inactivity tests are conducted wherein a connection is left idle and observed to confirm that automatic termination occurs as expected. Logs generated during these tests provide auditable evidence of compliance with the established disconnect policy.

by-components.description: The system employs a defined process implemented by ACME for cryptographic key management and establishment, ensuring that all cryptographic keys are established in accordance with the defined key management requirements. The process begins with the generation of cryptographic keys within a defined process implemented by ACME, which is designed to handle the secure creation of keys using algorithms that comply with specified standards and guidelines.Once generated, the distribution of keys is strictly controlled through a defined process implemented by ACME's permissions and access policies, ensuring that only authorized entities can retrieve or use the keys. These policies are configured to align with organizational requirements for least privilege and separation of duties, thereby minimizing the risk of unauthorized access.The storage of cryptographic keys is inherently secure within a defined process implemented by ACME, which provides a hardened repository that is resistant to tampering and unauthorized access. The vault leverages hardware security modules (HSMs) to protect the integrity of keys at rest.Access to cryptographic keys is audited and monitored continuously. A defined process implemented by ACME provides detailed logging of all operations, which allows for real-time alerting and post-incident analysis. Access controls are regularly reviewed and updated to adapt to changes in personnel or policy.Finally, the destruction of cryptographic keys is managed through a defined process implemented by ACME's secure deletion practices, which ensure that keys are rendered irrecoverable once they are no longer needed or when they reach the end of their lifecycle. This process includes overwriting memory locations where keys were stored and adheres to organizational policies and industry best practices for secure key disposal.Throughout this lifecycle, trust stores are managed diligently to include only approved trust anchors, with regular reviews to remove any expired or revoked certificates. All activities related to cryptographic key management are documented, with clear procedures established for each step. This ensures repeatability, accountability, and compliance with relevant laws and regulations.

ACME System

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: The Implementation Status for the control SC-21 is IMPLEMENTED

by-components.description: Azure DNS is configured to utilize DNSSEC, ensuring that both data origin authentication and data integrity verification are enforced for all name/address resolution requests. This configuration mandates that any response to a DNS query must be signed cryptographically, allowing the client resolvers to validate the authenticity of the response.Upon receiving a DNS query, Azure DNS checks if the requested domain supports DNSSEC and if so, it includes the digital signature in the response. The client resolver, equipped with the public key corresponding to the signing authority of the queried domain, validates this signature. If the validation is successful, it confirms that the response has not been tampered with and is from a legitimate source.This process takes place every time a DNS resolution request is made by any component within the system infrastructure. The continuous enforcement of DNSSEC validation ensures that any attempt at spoofing or tampering with DNS responses is detected and mitigated, maintaining the integrity and authenticity of the communication within the cloud environment.
ACME System

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: The Implementation Status for the control SC-22 is IMPLEMENTED

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components through DNS services, Azure DNS is utilized with a configuration that ensures fault tolerance and role separation. The mitigation process involves the following steps:1. Azure DNS and a defined process implemented by ACME is configured with at least two authoritative servers, one designated as the primary and the other as the secondary. This setup provides redundancy, ensuring continuous name resolution services in case one server fails.2. The DNS servers are deployed across two geographically separated network subnetworks. This geographical separation reduces the risk of both servers being affected by a single localized event, such as a natural disaster or power outage.3. Access controls are established for Azure DNS and a defined process implemented by ACME to enforce internal role separation. These controls ensure that only internal clients can access the internal DNS servers, which handle name and address resolution requests originating within the organization.4. Similarly, external role separation is enforced through access controls that restrict external clients to accessing only the external DNS servers designated for handling requests from outside the organization.5. Regular reviews of server configurations and access controls are conducted to verify compliance with these requirements. Automated tools are used to check server configurations for redundancy and geographic separation, while manual assessments review access control lists to confirm proper role separation.6. Any discrepancies found during assessments are addressed promptly to ensure that the actual state of the DNS infrastructure aligns with the desired state specifications.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure components and application components concerning information at rest, the following steps are implemented:1. Encryption mechanisms utilizing Azure Key Vault are deployed for all data at rest within the system's storage components, such as Azure SQL Server instances and Azure Storage accounts. This ensures that sensitive data is encrypted using robust cryptographic keys managed by Azure Key Vault, which provides secure key management and helps in maintaining the confidentiality and integrity of the data.2. Access control policies are strictly enforced on the Azure SQL Server instance "acme-fortify-v2-prod-db" to restrict access to authorized personnel only. These policies define who can access the data, under what conditions, and what operations they can perform. By controlling access, the system ensures that only legitimate users can interact with the data, thereby preventing unauthorized access and potential data breaches.3. Regular checks are conducted to retrieve the encryption status and access control settings for the "acme-fortify-v2-prod-db" SQL Server instance. Automated tools are utilized to perform these checks efficiently and ensure continuous compliance with the desired state of encryption and access controls.4. For Azure Storage accounts, a defined process implemented by ACME is in place to confirm that encryption is enabled for all data at rest using keys generated by Azure Key Vault. This step involves reviewing the storage account configurations to validate that encryption is not only enabled but also properly configured to use keys from Azure Key Vault.5. The system infrastructure is continuously monitored for any changes or anomalies that could affect the protection of information at rest. This includes frequent scanning for malicious code and ensuring that configurations or rule sets for security components like firewalls and intrusion detection systems remain intact and unaltered.6. When necessary, additional controls such as WORM technologies or secure offline storage may be employed to enhance the protection of information at rest, especially when online protections alone are deemed insufficient.

by-components.description: To ensure the cloud system infrastructure and application components are secure from known flaws, a multi-faceted approach is adopted that leverages both automated mechanisms and manual review processes.Firstly, Azure Virtual Machines (VMs) and Azure SQL Servers, which are integral to the system's operations, are configured to receive and install security updates automatically. This process is managed through Azure's built-in update management solutions, which are scheduled to apply patches during maintenance windows that minimize impact on operational continuity. The update process is governed by a predefined policy that stipulates the frequency and scope of updates, ensuring all system components remain compliant with the latest security standards.Secondly, Azure Monitor is utilized to continuously collect and analyze data regarding the system's health and performance. This tool is configured to specifically look for indicators that could suggest the presence of known flaws or vulnerabilities within the system components. It operates in real-time, providing immediate alerts should any potential issues be detected.In conjunction with Azure Monitor, Microsoft Defender for Endpoints serves as an additional layer of protection. It is employed to actively scan the system for threats and vulnerabilities. Through its Threat & Vulnerability Management capabilities, Microsoft Defender uses its API to query and identify known flaws across endpoints. This information is then used to prioritize remediation efforts based on the severity and potential impact of the identified vulnerabilities.Both Azure Monitor and Microsoft Defender feed their findings into an automated tracking system. This system maintains a comprehensive inventory of all known flaws relevant to the system components, along with their current status—whether they have been patched, require patching, or are under investigation. This tracking mechanism ensures that no known vulnerability remains unaddressed for an extended period.The actual state of the system is verified through periodic reviews of patch logs from Azure VMs and Azure SQL Server. These logs provide a historical record of all security updates that have been applied, allowing for manual verification against the desired state specification of having all applicable security updates installed.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, individual intrusion detection tools are integrated into a centralized system-wide intrusion detection system (IDS). This integration is achieved through a defined process implemented by ACME.Initially, a defined process implemented by ACME is configured as the central hub for security event management. It collects data from various sources, including a defined process implemented by ACME, which monitors web traffic, and a defined process implemented by ACME that provides endpoint security. These tools are connected using their respective APIs or connector services, enabling real-time data flow into the central IDS.Simultaneously, application security tools such as a defined process implemented by ACME are set up to perform static and dynamic analysis of the codebase, identifying vulnerabilities before deployment. The findings from a defined process implemented by ACME are then fed into a defined process implemented by ACME. Similarly, a defined process implemented by ACME is deployed to protect against common web vulnerabilities by filtering and monitoring HTTP traffic between the internet and the web service.For network-level security monitoring, ACME is employed to scrutinize network packets and identify potential intrusions. The alerts generated by ACME are also directed towards a defined process implemented by ACME for centralized logging and correlation.The configuration settings of each IDS tool are reviewed and adjusted to ensure they align with the organization's security policies and objectives. This includes setting appropriate alert thresholds, defining rules for event correlation, and establishing incident response procedures.Once operational, the system-wide IDS is continuously monitored. Automated scripts check the integration status of each individual IDS tool to confirm they remain connected to a defined process implemented by ACME. Any disruptions in data flow or anomalies in performance trigger an immediate investigation to maintain uninterrupted surveillance.The effectiveness of this integrated approach is periodically assessed through manual reviews. Security personnel scrutinize the configuration settings of each tool to validate their inclusion in the system-wide IDS and ensure that no component operates in isolation.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a multi-layered approach integrating security components with a defined process implemented by ACME is employed. Initially, the deployment of Azure Sentinel, a Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) is prioritized to provide real-time analysis of alerts and notifications. These SIEM systems are configured to collect data from host-based, network-based, transport-based, and storage-based event monitoring tools.The integration of these tools into the continuous monitoring strategy ensures that any anomalous activity is detected promptly. Network-based tools analyze traffic to identify patterns indicative of malicious activities, while host-based tools monitor individual system changes that could signal a breach or unauthorized modification.Transport-based monitoring safeguards the integrity of data in transit by inspecting and verifying secure communication protocols. Storage-based event monitoring continuously scans for unauthorized access or alterations to stored data. This comprehensive surveillance extends across all layers of the cloud infrastructure, including virtual machines, databases, applications, and APIs.A defined process implemented by ACME complements this technical implementation by instituting automated response procedures. In the event of a detected threat, predefined incident response protocols are triggered without delay. These protocols are designed to contain and mitigate the impact of security incidents while preserving forensic evidence for subsequent analysis.In parallel with these security measures, privacy risks associated with automated monitoring are assessed and documented through Privacy Impact Assessments. This ensures that any potential linkages between records across systems that could have unintended privacy consequences are identified and addressed in alignment with ACME's privacy program plan.Regular updates and patches to all monitoring tools are conducted to maintain their efficacy against evolving threats. Access to these tools is restricted to authorized personnel only, with stringent access controls in place to prevent unauthorized use that could compromise system integrity or violate privacy policies.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a comprehensive security strategy leveraging Azure Sentinel, Azure Monitor, and Microsoft Defender for Endpoints is employed.Initially, Azure Sentinel is configured with alert rules designed to detect indications of compromise or potential compromise. These rules are based on predefined or custom threat intelligence and behavioral analytics that continuously analyze data across the environment.Simultaneously, Microsoft Defender for Endpoints is deployed on all eligible endpoints within the cloud environment. This endpoint detection and response solution monitors for signs of malicious activity and software vulnerabilities, providing real-time protection and automated investigation capabilities.Azure Monitor complements these efforts by collecting and analyzing performance metrics and log data from various cloud resources. It helps in identifying unusual activities that could signify a security event.Once the alert rules are in place, Azure Sentinel actively monitors the system-generated logs and data streams for incidents that match the defined criteria. When an incident is detected, Azure Sentinel generates an alert.To ensure prompt action, these alerts are configured to be transmitted via multiple communication channels. The system is set up to send notifications through electronic mail messages, text messaging, or directly through integrated communication platforms like Microsoft Teams. This ensures that relevant organizational personnel, including system administrators and security officers, receive timely information to initiate an appropriate response.In addition to real-time alerting, the system supports incident investigation and threat hunting activities. Security analysts can leverage Azure Sentinel's advanced query capabilities to probe deeper into suspicious events or patterns identified by automated alerts.Regular assessments are conducted to verify the effectiveness of the alerting mechanisms. Test alerts are generated and transmitted through the established channels to confirm that notifications reach the intended recipients without delay.
ACME System

by-components.description: The mitigation of threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components is achieved through a systematic approach that integrates various security components and DevOps management activities. The process begins with the deployment of a defined process implemented by ACME, which serves as a central platform for collecting and correlating logs and events from different monitoring tools. The defined process implemented by ACME is configured to ingest data from all relevant sources within the cloud environment, ensuring comprehensive visibility across the system.Next, a defined process implemented by ACME is utilized to monitor network traffic. This tool is specifically tailored to analyze inbound and outbound communications, flagging any suspicious activity that may indicate a potential threat. The configuration of the defined process implemented by ACME includes setting up alerts and integrating its output with the defined process implemented by ACME to enrich the overall monitoring data.On the endpoint level, a defined process implemented by ACME is employed to keep track of host activities. It continuously scans for signs of malicious behavior on individual devices, leveraging its built-in analytics to spot anomalies. The defined process implemented by ACME feeds its findings into the defined process implemented by ACME, contributing to the multi-layered surveillance strategy.For protection against malicious code, a defined process implemented by ACME is engaged. It scans applications and codebases for vulnerabilities and malware signatures. The results from the defined process implemented by ACME are also directed into the defined process implemented by ACME, where they are correlated with other data points to identify complex attack vectors that single tools might miss.These security capabilities are orchestrated in a manner that ensures continuous monitoring. Alerts generated by any of these tools trigger predefined response procedures, which are documented and regularly updated to reflect emerging threats and changes in the system architecture.By integrating these disparate monitoring tools—the defined process implemented by ACME, the defined process implemented by ACME, the defined process implemented by ACME, and the defined process implemented by ACME—the cloud system achieves a robust defense posture. This integrated approach facilitates the early detection of threats by highlighting correlations that might indicate coordinated or sophisticated attacks. It ensures that no single point of failure can compromise the system's security and that the organization maintains a high level of situational awareness regarding its cyber health.
ACME System

by-components.description: The mitigation of threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components through security components and DevOps management activities is achieved by implementing a comprehensive monitoring strategy that leverages Azure Network Security Groups (NSGs) and Azure Virtual Networks (VNets).Firstly, Azure NSGs are configured to define and control inbound and outbound traffic rules at external interfaces. These rules are designed to filter traffic based on protocol, source and destination IP addresses, port numbers, and direction (inbound or outbound). The NSGs are regularly updated in accordance with ACME's security policies to ensure that only legitimate traffic is allowed to pass through the external interfaces.Secondly, within Azure VNets, subnetworks are established to segment the cloud environment into distinct security zones. Each subnet is associated with an NSG to enforce traffic controls at these interior points. This segmentation allows for more granular monitoring and analysis of traffic patterns within the cloud environment.For the detection of covert exfiltration of information, specifically steganography, ACME deploys specialized monitoring tools capable of analyzing outbound communications traffic. These tools are integrated with Azure VNets and are configured to inspect packet payloads for anomalies or indicators of steganography.The DevOps team is responsible for the deployment and management of these monitoring tools. They ensure that the tools are kept up-to-date with the latest threat intelligence and signatures for detecting covert channels. The team also conducts regular reviews of monitoring logs and alerts generated by these tools to identify potential exfiltration attempts.In addition to automated monitoring, manual assessments are conducted periodically to scrutinize outbound traffic for any signs of steganography that might not be detected by automated means. This includes examining packet sizes, timing intervals, and other metadata that could indicate covert communication channels.All detected incidents are logged, and alerts are generated for further investigation by the security operations team. In case of a confirmed exfiltration attempt, incident response procedures are initiated to contain the threat, eradicate the presence of unauthorized entities, recover from the incident, and apply lessons learned to improve future defenses.

This preemptive measure helps in identifying vulnerabilities or unauthorized code alterations early in the development cycle.

Custom queries are created within Log Insights to pinpoint unusual activities that could indicate a security breach.For each of these tools, incident response procedures are defined and documented. Historical records of all detected events are maintained as part of this process, ensuring that there is a trail for forensic analysis and legal purposes.In addition to technical measures, administrative policies are in place requiring regular review of security alerts and logs by qualified personnel. These reviews are scheduled at regular intervals and any findings are documented and addressed according to established incident response protocols.

by-components.description: Input validation mechanisms are integrated into the cloud system to mitigate threats associated with invalid or malicious data entering the system's infrastructure and application components. These mechanisms are designed to ensure that all data inputs conform to predefined criteria for syntax, semantics, character set, length, numerical range, and acceptable values.The process begins with the definition of validity checks for information inputs. This includes specifying acceptable data formats, character sets, and value ranges for each input field within applications. For instance, a field requiring a numerical input between 1 and 100 will reject any data outside this range or any non-numeric input.Security components responsible for input validation are configured to perform these checks before data is processed or stored. This is achieved by employing filters, validators, or sanitizers that examine every piece of input against the established criteria. Inputs failing to meet these standards are rejected or sanitized to remove potentially harmful elements.DevOps management activities play a crucial role in maintaining the effectiveness of input validation processes. These activities include regular updates to validation rules in response to emerging threats, continuous integration and deployment practices that incorporate security testing into the development lifecycle, and ongoing monitoring to detect and respond to input validation failures.Additionally, structured messages used for communication between software modules or system components are constructed with proper encoding to prevent attacker-supplied inputs from being interpreted as control information or metadata. Prescreening of inputs prior to their interpretation by software modules ensures that only intended commands are executed.

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a comprehensive acquisition strategy is established, leveraging procurement methods that prioritize supply chain security. This strategy includes the use of blind or filtered buys when necessary to obscure the end-use of critical components, thus reducing the risk of targeted tampering or counterfeit insertion.Contract tools are tailored to include language that mandates tamper-evident packaging and restricts purchases from suppliers that cannot demonstrate trustworthy practices. These contracts also stipulate requirements for secure handling and transportation, ensuring that components remain uncompromised throughout the distribution process.A supply chain risk assessment is conducted to determine the most effective strategies, tools, and methods for each procurement. The results of this assessment guide decisions on supplier selection, incentivizing those who adopt robust security measures and provide transparency into their processes.All personnel involved in procurement activities receive training and education on supply chain risks and mitigation strategies. Awareness programs ensure that staff members can identify red flags and understand the protocols for employing mitigation strategies effectively.Documentation protection requirements are included in contracts to safeguard development plans, documentation, and evidence against unauthorized access or alteration. These requirements align with ACME's security and privacy needs, ensuring that sensitive information related to the supply chain is adequately protected.Contracts also include clauses that prohibit tainted or counterfeit components. Suppliers are required to adhere to these terms strictly, with mechanisms in place for verification and validation of compliance.Procurement methods incorporate regular reviews of supplier practices, including audits and assessments to confirm adherence to agreed-upon security standards. Non-compliance results in corrective actions or reconsideration of supplier contracts.

By adhering to these structured activities, ACME ensures that its cloud system infrastructure components and application components remain secure against threats arising from supply chain vulnerabilities.

To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components, a comprehensive approach integrating security components and DevOps management activities is employed.To ensure compliance with organizational security policies, monitoring tools like Microsoft Azure Sentinel and Veracode are deployed. These tools provide continuous oversight of supply chain entities' adherence to security policies. Regular verification through these systems ensures that any deviations from policy are quickly identified and addressed.Each step in this process involves specific roles within the organization, following established policies and "a defined process implemented by ACME." By adhering to these structured activities, ACME ensures that its cloud system infrastructure components and application components remain secure against threats arising from supply chain vulnerabilities.
ACME System

by-components.description: To mitigate threats to the cloud system's infrastructure and application components through tamper resistance and detection, the following steps are implemented:1. Define the specific systems or system components that require inspection for tamper resistance and detection. This includes both physical hardware within data centers as well as critical software components that form part of the cloud infrastructure.2. Establish a frequency at which these identified systems or components should be inspected. The frequency is based on risk assessments, considering factors such as the sensitivity of the information processed and the potential impact of tampering.3. Develop clear indications that trigger the need for an inspection. These indications include any changes in packaging, specifications, factory location, or the entity from which parts are purchased, as well as when individuals return from travel to high-risk locations.4. Implement "a defined process implemented by ACME" for conducting both physical and logical inspections. Physical inspections involve checking for intact tamper-evident seals and any signs of unauthorized access to hardware. Logical inspections consist of integrity checks on software and firmware to detect unauthorized modifications.5. Utilize automated tools where possible to monitor for changes that may indicate tampering or the need for an inspection. This includes monitoring supply chain data for changes in component origins and maintaining logs of system modifications.6. Maintain detailed inspection logs that record each inspection's date, findings, and any actions taken in response to the findings. These logs support adherence to the defined inspection frequency and provide an audit trail.7. Train personnel responsible for conducting inspections in proper procedures and ensure they are aware of what constitutes an indication for an inspection.8. Regularly review and update the tamper resistance and detection procedures to adapt to new threats or changes in the organization's operational environment.

resources.title: SSP Signature
resources.remarks: FedRAMP is formulating guidelines for handling digital/electronic signatures in OSCAL, and welcome feedback on solutions.For now, FedRAMP recommends one of the following:* Render the OSCAL SSP content as a PDF that is digitally signed and attached. Render the OSCAL SSP content as a printed page that is physically signed, scanned, and attached. If your organization prefers another approach, please seek prior approval from the FedRAMP PMO.
